body:
@vfonic Figaro 2.0 (in development) adds a `figaro exec` command, which uses Ruby to load your Figaro configuration into `ENV` and then execute some other command of your choosing.

I'm not very familiar with Node.js development but `figaro exec your/node/command` might be interesting for that use case.

That might work!

I'm curious how it would work after deployment. ðŸ¤”
It might be a bit inconvenient to have to add `figaro exec` before every command. Plus, heroku is precompiling assets automatically, so, in order for this to work there, we'd have to override "assets:precompile" task to get ENV vars into webpacker/webpack. I'm not sure actually...

I'm eager to be the beta tester if that helps! :)
I'm also very open to the creation of a JS Figaro sidecar (by somebody else! ðŸ˜œ), although I might suggest avoiding replicating Figaro v1 at this point, in favor of v2.
Please consider merging @laserlemon
I just ran into this, and this gets it bundling again. Rails 6 needs thor 1.0.
For Fsake, can someone merge this and release a new version of Figaro? Firago also conflicts with **Solargraph** which depends on thor version 1.0.

@Rambou I've volunteered to get this merged and updated, though it'll be a few days before I have time to finish that up. 

In the meantime, pointing at @Deekor's branch should get you up and running. It is what I'm doing currently.
Looks like @laserlemon is offline ... is anyone maintaining a fork of this project?

We have a fork with a couple of changes (looks like 255 other people do too!). It may mean someone (...) will have to make a statement of intent to hard fork, rename and release as a new gem if we can't get hold him. I see he actually [works at Github](https://github.com/laserlemon). I will try contacting him there.

Hello and sorry for dropping off the map! I have all of the excuses you'd expect: family and full-time job. I still care very much about Figaro but have had difficulty finding and prioritizing time for its developemnt _and_ gauging its continued value in the community. I'm attempting to provide some solution to both of those problems by opening my [sponsorship profile](https://github.com/sponsors/laserlemon) and I've added an **UPDATE** section to the [README](https://github.com/laserlemon/figaro#readme) with this information as well.

Sorry this answer doesn't provide more _immediate_ results, but I hope that you'll stick with me as I try to navigate back to active Figaro development! ðŸ’›
@laserlemon are you open to taking on additional maintainers?
Yes, I'll offer too. Its a great gem, we'd be very keen to keep it maintained.
Yes, I'll offer too. Its a great gem, we'd be very keen to keep it maintained.

@tomgallagher i certainly wouldn't do 2.  I just dealt with a project where all the keys were in the credentials.yml.enc (yes, including dev and test) and a dev's laptop was stolen.  even encrypted, the keys were still committed to the repo and had to be changed.

I'm currently working on an s3 approach to getting files on a system for config and I'll let you know how that goes.

@tomgallagher (and those who might find this later) follow up from my previous comment.

we used the aws-s3 sdk and have copies of our files on an s3 bucket.  Then, during deploy, our capistrano task pulls down the file to the shared folder from the bucket.  The main thing to leverage is SSHKit's file stream for upload, since that is what the s3 object will return.  This is one method that works, and not the only way to accomplish this.

```ruby
# taken from a Capistrano task
s3 = Aws::S3::Resource.new(
       region: fetch(:aws_region),
       credentials: Aws::Credentials.new(
         fetch(:aws_access_key),
         fetch(:aws_secret_key)
       )
     )
obj = s3.bucket(:aws_s3_bucket).object(:s3_file_path)
upload! obj.get.body, :server_file_path
```

My bad, I figured out what was the error, - wrong syntax:
```
ENV.fetch['DATABASE_HOST']
```
should be
```
ENV.fetch('DATABASE_HOST', 'some_defaut_value_if_not_found')
```

Priority of variables loaded, from lowest to highest:

1. Defaults declared in the `Envfile`, i.e. `string :foo, default: "Foo"`
2. Values declared in `.env.yml` files. Last declaration wins, overriding previous declarations of the same named variable.
3. `ENV` variables declared on the system.

With this in mind, I don't think `defaults` is a confusing method name. I'd suggest something that suggests the precedence of the files being loaded:

```ruby
source ".env.yml"
source ".env.test.yml", if: -> { Rails.env.test? }

load ".env.yml"
load ".env.test.yml", if: -> { Rails.env.test? }

provide ".env.yml"
provide ".env.test.yml", if: -> { Rails.env.test? }
```

`defaults` makes it unclear what values will actually be loaded.

I think the strategy for loading really depends on if you expect value files to act like cascading stylesheets, where you can provide overrides in special conditions, then multiple DSL `source` calls makes the most sense. If you expect variables to be more mutually exclusive and independent, then I think a single YAML file with keys makes more sense. I have concerns in either situation.

- Environment files that depend on values previously declared in another environment file seems risky and unpredictable. Cascading is tricky if you don't see how things are being sourced. I'd rather see a single file that has all the overrides declared in them so there's fewer places to check to determine where something was sourced.
- A single env file that has keyed value sets is nice for seeing what's overridden where, but there's a good chance you might want to have overrides for one environment (`test`) in source control, but not from another (`production`). So in that case, I'd rather have separate env files for each environment I'd be loading.
- If you're using a single keyed environment file and passing the key in the `Envfile`, you miss out on cascaded loading unless you combine it with subsequent conditional loading, i.e.

```ruby
source ".env.yml", key: :base
source ".env.yml", key: :test, if: -> { Rails.env.test? }
```

I guess it all depends on what your goals are, but I think separating the idea of `defaults` and `sourced` variables is important for the clarifying the ideas in this discussion.

**Update:** After mulling this over some more, I'm leaning toward a single YAML configuration file with the ability to key the file according to the application environment. To define the application environment (since Figaro will no longer be Rails-dependent), I'm adding the `environment` method to the DSL. For example:

```ruby
# env.rb
environment key: "APP_ENV", default: "development"

defaults "env.yml"

string :stripe_publishable_key
string :stripe_secret_key
decimal :price, default: "9.99"
```

```yaml
# env.yml
stripe_publishable_key: "pk_test_NlsxCBp2TPGWyQeHUFw4uj4L"
stripe_secret_key: "sk_test_iHBheVvfdegliMwizMi2uiOe"

production:
  stripe_publishable_key: "pk_live_uoExPgxfIG7bBXMAMyqHfB9b"
  stripe_secret_key: "sk_live_KbhHZzgpzWIEsOoBOnatXUjo"
```

As for the `defaults` method naming, I hear you. I'm not sold on it either. I'm not sold on the alternatives set forth yet either. I'll keep rolling that one around.

When it comes to committing multiple default values for a given key, let's say for the `development` and `test` environments while keeping the `production` value out of source control, there are a couple of options:

1. Load multiple YAML configuration files, some committed and some not.
2. Allow environment-dependent default values in the envfile.

I'm not sure what to do about this one just yet either. I don't like the idea of multiple YAML configuration files because it's harder to track down what values are where. Plus it's more likely that something that's not supposed to get committed does get committed. Here's what option 2 might look like in practice:

```ruby
# env.rb
environment key: "APP_ENV", default: "development"

defaults "env.yml"

string :hello, default: { development: "developer", test: "computer" }
```

Anyway, just dumping some thoughts here. Feel free to chime in!

Hello @mrusson I have also tried to replicate this error and was unable to. The rake tasks are working fine for me. I agree with @jk1dd and would dig into your application.yml for a syntax error. I am running macOS sierra 10.12.6 and the project I tested in was using ruby 2.3.0 and rails 5.0.2
I had a similar issue. Check your `application.yml` configuration; I bet you have something set to a hash instead of a string value.

@hlascelles - your builds are failing because the Travis config picks up different Bundler gemfiles for different Ruby versions (in `figaro/gemfiles`) so you'll need to add `combustion` to each of those.

I looked into this and found that if you have 
```
# Ignore application configuration
/config/application.yml
``` 
in your .gitignore, nothing will be appended. However, if you removed either of the two lines, it will append both lines and make the file redundant.

It seems that figaro should really only care about `/config/application.yml`. I'll put in a PR for this fix.
We shouldn't hardcode the path also. So it should just care about application.yml
@laserlemon your views?
As of today, we should hardcore the path because that's exactly where Figaro will look for it. Thank you for checking on this!

Respectfully, I have a small PR for an addition to the heroku commands section of the README. I think the functionality of simply the `heroku config` command is worth mentioning because I have found it to be very handy when using this gem.
this information is available in the heroku panel.
Thank you!
Are you sure `Rails.env` is actually returning `"staging"` on your staging server?

I use Capistrano to deploy my Rails application and I've set the corresponding `deploy` environment:
```ruby
# config/deploy/staging.rb
set :stage, :staging

# config/deploy/production.rb
set :stage, :production
```

Here is my puma server log on startup:
```shell
Puma starting in cluster mode...
    * Version 3.6.0 (ruby 2.2.2-p95), codename: Sleepy Sunday Serenity
    * Min threads: 0, max threads: 16
    * Environment: staging # <= Rails environment ?
    * Process workers: 2
    * Phased restart available
```
I assume that the `Rails.env` should match the corresponding capistrano environment used to deploy ? I still don't understand why it works for `production` but not `staging`.

Thanks !
To be sure, I'd use `rails console` on staging to see what `Rails.env` is set to.

`rails console` on the staging server doesn't work for me (it throws many errors from gem specified in the development group of Gemfile and not available in staging).

So I have to write `bundle exec rails console staging` in order to make it to work and obviously the `Rails.env` give me `staging`.
Sounds like you may need to set `RAILS_ENV=staging` on your server. That may solve these issues.

Thanks but setting `RAILS_ENV=staging` didn't change anything ðŸ˜ž 

I added a htpasswd protection in my `staging` environment file. That's weird because it's use config defined in `application.yml` as well (under `staging` key) and it works.

```yml
# application.yml
staging: 
  htpasswd_name: 'my_name'
  htpasswd_password: 'my_password'
```

```ruby
# environments/staging.rb
config.middleware.insert_before(::Rack::Runtime, "::Rack::Auth::Basic", 'Staging environment') do |u, p|
  u == Figaro.env.htpasswd_name && p == Figaro.env.htpasswd_password
end
```

Does the error could come from `database.yml` file ? Is the file loaded before Rails env is defined ?
```yml
# application.yml
database_name: 'my_database_development'
staging:
  database_name: 'my_database_staging' 
production: 
  database_name: 'my_database_production'
```
```yml
# database.yml
staging:
  <<: *default
  database: <%= Figaro.env.database_name %> # => returns 'my_database_development'
```

That's strange but you could be on to something there. I'm afraid I won't be able to help much more without a failing test case. And I even think the Figaro test suite has a test that uses values from `application.yml` _in_ `database.yml`. Check it out and keep me posted with what you find!
Thanks for your help and time. I will try to investigate more about that.

Just after replying I finally figured out why it wasn't working:

I was defining two times the `staging` key in my `application.yml` and the first properties (from database) where erased by the seconds ones (htpasswd). About the `production` key, it was working properly because I only defined it once.

To fix it, I had to inherit from the first `staging`, so my final solution is as follow:
```yml
# application.yml
staging: &staging # <= important
  database_name: 'my_database_staging'

...

staging:
  <<: *staging # <= important
  htpasswd_name: 'my_htpasswd_name'
  ...
```

That was a very vicious bug !

Your assessment is totally correct. Currently, Figaro depends on some Rails constructs like `Rails.env` and `Rails.root`, which means that the `before_configuration` Rails hook is as early as we can load Figaro. The alternative here would be to defer requiring `bonsai-elasticsearch-rails` until after Figaro is loaded. For example:

```ruby
# Gemfile

gem "figaro"
gem "bonsai-elasticsearch-rails", require: false
```

```ruby
# config/application.rb

Bundler.require(*Rails.groups)

module FooBar
  class Application < Rails::Application
    require "bonsai-elasticsearch-rails"
  end
end
```

Not ideal but I hope that helps!

@TheNotary Rest assured, myself and a colleague are getting the same test failures that you are. We are currently looking into fixes for the heroku_set_spec. In regards to the "run_simple" command you mentioned, I am looking into that as well.

@TheNotary as an experiment, add this to `./lib/figaro/cli/heroku_set.rb`: 

```ruby
    class HerokuSet < Task
      def run
        raise system('which heroku').to_s #add this line please
        system(configuration, command)
      end

```

On my end, the first path object is pointing to `/usr/local/bin/heroku`. Based on the CommandInterceptor module, I think it should point to `./spec/support/bin/heroku` so the problem is that Aruba is either using a different environment where it can find the real heroku or it's caching the location.

I had to use `raise` instead of a debugger like pry or byebug because Aruba is also running in a way where i can't interact with the debugger once we hit it.

And are you getting burnt out maintaining this @laserlemon?  Looks like the merges haven't been done in a while.

I haven't tested all of the features but I can confirm the basics (i.e., declaring ENVs)  of Figaro works on Rails 5.

The heroku toolbet gem can get env vars with `heroku config:get` I think.  Since that work has already been done, I think a best approach to this problem is to create a `figaro:env_to_yml` command that takes in (perhaps from STDIN) a string of env variables and outputs an appliaction.yml file.  This saves us the step of having to conver `=` signs to `:` signs and such.  Ultimately the workflow would become:

```
my_app $  heroku config -s | figaro config:env_to_yml > heroku_application.yml
```

The reason I think to do it this way using pipes and such is that there are getting to be _many_ PaaS code bases out there and Figaro should probably try to be as agnostic and multi-purposed as possible.  

What do you think, and did you make any progress?  I'm thinking I might make a `figaro-config-addons` gem to add this functionality to figaro faster to allow time for review, discussion and bug fixing.  

It's important that we have a backwards and forwards compatible way (a way to set configs).  As it stands, `figaro heroku:set` automatically slurps up the application.yml file, converting it to an env format (without new line characters) and then sets the variables in heroku using herokutoolbelt CLI app (an explicit dependency).  Since Heroku is popular, this method is arguably helpful, but it isn't useful when the developer needs to import vars into dokku, Deis, etc, etc.  To this developer, an additional command `figaro config:yml_to_env` would be helpful.  I'll rewrite my PR... add tests... then see about pulling it into it's own figaro-config-addons gem and put it up for review.

You should write your `application.yml` to the exact case your application will use. While Heroku suggests a certain convention, there's no guarantee that everybody will (or can) use that convention consistently across the board. For that reason, Figaro won't automatically upcase, downcase, or otherwise. Hope that makes sense!

Now I know the 'why' ;-) Here's the answer from Heroku:

> The behaviour of config vars in this case is due to the underlying Linux operating system being case sensitive. "Behind the scenes" config vars are just a way of managing Unix environment variables to be set on the dynos and as such, our handling of these is fairly minimal to keep them consistent with any other Linux based hosts - if we started adapting the case automatically you might find situations where it didn't work locally whereas it did on Heroku.

As mentioned in #189, this breaks true case insensitivity for ENV variable lookup. Your example implementation of `get_value` would not find an ENV variable named `Foo_Bar` when calling `Figaro.env.foo_bar`. This may be a reasonable change but it _is_ a breaking one so we'll need to consider the consequences.

No, in that case it would look for `::ENV["FOO_BAR"]` instead of finding `::ENV["Foo_Bar"]`.

It is not run twice. It is run once for each environment (dev & test). 
But from `database.yml` perspective all properties have the same values as where loaded into `ENV` at the moment of application initialization with the exact environment in that exact moment (e.g. `development`). In your example it drops `rails_dev` for dev env and then drops `rails_dev` for test env.

I'm not sure what @ender4 did to solve their issue, but I've had a couple of issues getting this to work properly. Some of them are rather strange, I'm not sure of a better place to put this info, so I'll put it here. The first problem I had, which @ender4 addresses above, is that you must put your ENV['VARIABLE'] inside <%= %> erb brackets. The next issue I had is the main reason I'm writting this comment. **If, like me, you decide to start your database password with an '!', things get really fun.** if you only use one set of quotes and try to embed from config/application.yml to config/database.yml

in application.yml
`
DB_PASS: "!asdfadsf"
`

in database.yml
`
password: <%= ENV['DB_PASS'] %>
`

The quotes you put around DB_PASS in config/application.yml get stripped away and your left with

`
password: !ajdkfasdfdf
`

This is not what we want because starting a yaml variable with an '!' creates a yaml tag, http://www.yaml.org/spec/1.2/spec.html#id2761292, and that will not get properly feed into your database.

In order to get around this issue, we have to nest double quotes inside single quotes to ensure there are still quotes around the value when it is parsed from database.yml.

config/application.yml
`
password: '"!adsfadsfadsf"'
`

 I hope this saves someone time in the future.

TL;DR
If your password begins with an '!', you must double quote it.
`
DB_PASS: '"!asdklfadjslfk"'
`

@laserlemon the message is showing AW/SMTP keys, even though they are set to follow the documentation in Figaro.

The issue is that Figaro doesn't support nested structures. The warning is trying to tell you that the value for `"aws"` is a hash rather than a string and that the value will be converted to the string representation of that hash (`Hash#to_s`).

There's a not about this at the bottom of the [example section](https://github.com/laserlemon/figaro#example) of the readme.

Your configuration file should be a simple key/value mapping, with the exception of Rails-environment-specific configurations, which are nested under a key for the current `Rails.env`.

I hope that helps! Let me know if you have any more questions.

For anyone that is still bothered by this, the issue is that Spring does not watch aplication.yml by default.  All you have to do is add this to a spring.rb initializer:

`Spring.watch "config/application.yml"`

Restart spring and you should be good to go.

Okay, thanks. I just did a little digging and here's what I came up withâ€¦

My test works because this is the code I test to ensure configuration is available immediately following application inheritance:

``` ruby
module Example
  class Application < Rails::Application
    config.foo = ENV["foo"]
  end
end
```

This works. I'll get to why.

On the other hand, this code will not work:

``` ruby
module Example
  class Application < Rails::Application
    puts ENV["foo"]
  end
end
```

The reason the first example works and the second doesn't is because the `before_configuration` hook (the earliest hook available) that Figaro ties into doesn't run until the new _instance_ of the `Example::Application` is initialized. Initializing the singleton application instance happens when the `instance` method is called on the `Example::Application` class. It just so happens that the `config` class method [delegates to `instance`](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v4.2.1/railties/lib/rails/railtie/configurable.rb#L9).

So the fact that my example evaluates `config` before it evaluates `ENV["foo"]` avoids the issue by initializing the instance _just_ in time. In your example, by the time you evaluate `ENV["foo"]`, the `instance` has yet to be initialized.

Off the top of my head, I'm not sure how to get around this, outside of the `Figaro.load` workaround you've already come up with. Thoughts?

So I'm thinking this is a regression in Rails, since this was working before Rails 4.2. The problem you stated is exactly correct, the `before_configuration` hook is actually never run until `config` is called for the first time, which lazily loads a config instance. So, this actually works too:

``` ruby
module Example
  class Application < Rails::Application
    config
    puts ENV["foo"]
  end
end
```

I'd say the smartest thing to do would be to add a note in the documentation and submit an issue about the regression to Rails.

Just check your application.yml file, and for any value showing like numbers, just quote them. For example: 

FACEBOOK_APP_ID: '12345678'

Seems there's no direct configuration provided for this, at least for the Rails usage. The `figaro install` allows you to pass in the path, e.g `figaro install -p config/passport.yml` - but this only creates the file, and appends it to the git ignore. But then the gem will still look for the file at `config/application.yml`.

This works when used in an initializer:

``` ruby
# config/initializers/figaro.rb
Figaro.application.path = Rails.root.join('config', 'passport.yml')
Figaro.load
```

Although it's more of a workaround, as `Figaro.load` would be getting called for the second time here.

Yup, it's the workaround I ended up using for the time being. The crux is that because Figaro runs on before_configuration, you can't even config it with an initializer. I wonder where we could make space to put some settings.
Also to note that the param in the workaround will be ignored by `figaro heroku:set`

Sure, let me explain the reasoning behind this a little more. The idea is that this warning may very well be telling you something that you don't know. Take this scenario:

A developer deploys his or her application to production with an `application.yml` file. The configuration file contains a key named `foo`. If the production server's `ENV` already has a `foo` key, the `foo` value from `application.yml` will be ignored. It's very possible that the developer was unaware that the server already had this `ENV` variable set. This is most common with generic key naming like `USER`.

This situation can be (and has been) very confusing for developers in the past because they can't readily see why the value in `application.yml` would not be respected.

Upon further thought, it seems as though you'd only get this warning if you have `ENV` variables set on Heroku _and_ have an `application.yml` as well. Can you confirm that that's the case? If so, it's advised to use either one approach or the other rather than both at once.

Please let me know if you have any questions about all of that :point_up:. I hope I'm making things clearer rather than muddying the waters!

Unfortunately, those warnings are very intentional. What you're describing very closely mimics a potential production server scenario in which `application.yml` is used but some pre-existing environment variable exists on the server. You can safely ignore those warning messages if you're aware of the collision (which you are, of course). I'd also consider a pull request that silences these warnings based on the presence of some environment variable such as `ENV["FIGARO_SILENCE_WARNINGS"]`.

The intent of `require_keys` is exactly that: to fail early rather than during a user's interaction with the system. If you want it to send an email, you can certainly do that:

``` ruby
begin
  Figaro.require_keys("some", "keys")
rescue Figaro::MissingKeys
  # Send an email alert
end
```

You can use the `before_script` configuration in your `.travis.yml`:

``` yaml
before_script: "cp application.example.yml application.yml"
```

Of course, that assumes you have an example file committed. Otherwise, you can look into how to set ENV variables via `.travis.yml`. You can also encrypt the ENV variables before adding to `.travis.yml` if that's a concern.

I'd like to see the casting of the keys and values to strings inside of `application.rb`. As it is now, we don't get the benefit of the non-string key/value warning messages. I'm not sure exactly where this should go, however.
Rather than merging laserlemon/master into your branch, please rebase your commits against laserlemon/master. I'd like for the pull request to be a fast-forward of master.
We'll need a reliably failing test (on Travis) to really be able to protect against regression.

It should also be mentioned that numeric values in a Figaro configuration file are not supported. This is from the readme:

> Please note: ENV is a simple key/value store. All values will be converted to strings. Deeply nested configuration structures are not possible.

This is because `ENV` can only store strings.

In normal usage, Figaro will [complain](https://github.com/laserlemon/figaro/blob/ed7244b/lib/figaro/application.rb#L72-L73) about non-string keys or values. Any explicit test that asserts numeric values will work should also assert that the warnings are provided.

Please note: ENV is a simple key/value store. All values will be converted to strings. Deeply nested configuration structures are not possible.
@smilansky how can I put arrays in the ENV[]?

@smilansky You can't do it. `ENV` is only capable of storing strings. You'll have to store a delimited value like:

``` yaml
user_ids: "12,34,56"
```

and do the parsing yourself:

``` ruby
ENV["user_ids"].split(",").map(&:to_i)
```

Hope that helps!
regards!

I store Arrays no problem, you just have to reparse the value (using `YAML.load`) to get an array, for example:

In application.yml:
`ADMINS: [[Foo, foo@bar.com, changeme],[Baz, baz@bae.org, changeme]]`

In seeds.rb:

```
YAML.load(ENV['ADMINS']).each do |admin|
    user = User.find_or_create_by_email :name => admin[0], :email => admin[1], :password => admin[2], :password_confirmation => admin[2]
    user.add_role :admin
end
```

I am also running into this issue but I get the key doesn't exist just with `bundle exec rails c`.  Any solution to this?  Should I remove spring?
looks like it's because spring didn't reload.  Just stopping and starting spring fixed it for me.

Spring isn't set up to recognise application.yml as important.
If you change application.rb Spring will detect it and automatically restart. 
If you add
config/spring.rb

```
Spring.watch "config/application.yml"
```

And then in a terminal 

```
 touch config/application.rb
```

(Just tells spring to reload so it picks up the config above)

Then every time you change application.yml spring will notice and restart.

Hope that helps somebody. Spent 2 hours thinking there was something wrong with my code before I realised that the env variables weren't updating....

This is solved in version 1.0.0.rc1, specifically in [this commit](https://github.com/laserlemon/figaro/commit/ac00b48025d38819615c926ad394a23948d6f914).

The approach was to have Figaro keep track of what keys _it_ has set internally vs. what's been set externally. As of 1.0.0.rc1, Figaro will overwrite internally set values without hesitation.

@raul, thank you for the code! I agree that documentation is important for Figaro configuration. This is something I haven't communicated well enough in the past or even now after rewriting the readme. Here's the pattern I've used:

I commit a `config/application.example.yml` file to the repo with `nil` values. Each key or group of keys that warrant explanation get a block of comments above.

``` yaml
# Pusher: realtime messaging
#
# Your Pusher app_id, key and secret are all application-specific. You can sign
# up for a free "sandbox" account and create a new application at:
#
#   https://app.pusher.com
#
pusher_app_id: ~
pusher_key: ~
pusher_secret: ~

# Stripe: payment processing
#
# You can sign up at Stripe for free and your credentials can be found at:
#
#   https://manage.stripe.com/account/apikeys
#
# Be sure to us the appropriate key pair (test vs. live)!
#
stripe_api_key: ~
stripe_publishable_key: ~
```

There are a few benefits to this approach:
1. YAML has great support for comments. These are easily written and read. Nicely formatted comments inside the `require` method call would require using heredocs. Plus, semantically, these really are comments that we're discussing.
2. Optional configuration keys get the same love when it comes to documentation as their required counterparts.
3. Configuration keys often travel in packs. Pusher has a few. Stripe has a couple. Rather than documenting each key individually, groups of keys can be documented at once without being redundant.

So far, we've had very little trouble using Figaro with this convention. The problems we did have were due to not having a way to require keys during boot time to alert a developer to their absence. The `require` method solves that for us now, as we simply hop over to the example file.

I agree with you that some sort of `figaro status` command like you describe would be pretty great, but the code cleverness that may be required to get there using an example file might not be worth it, not to mention the formalization of one example file convention.

I have had thoughts about expanding the ability of the `require` method to accept a hash as well, but my take is intended to be correctional rather than instructive.

``` ruby
Figaro.require(
  "pusher_app_id" => /\A\d+\z/,
  "pusher_key" => /\A[0-9a-f]{20}\z/,
  "pusher_secret" => /\A[0-9a-f]{20}\z/,
  "stripe_api_key" => /\Ask_(test|live)_[0-9a-zA-Z]{24}\z/,
  "stripe_publishable_key" => /\Apk_(test|live)_[0-9a-zA-Z]{24}\z/
)
```

This may actually make more sense as a separate `validate` method and would be used to prevent bungled values. Validation could still be run (allowing `nil`) on optional configuration keys. Matching would use either the `===` or `=~` method so a custom validator could also be used in place of any of the regular expressions.

Thoughts?

Also, you forgot one important piece from the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/laserlemon/figaro/blob/1e32d61/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-contribute).

Here are some ideas:
- When reporting an issue:
  1. Do a small search on the issues tracker before submitting your issue to see if it was already reported / fixed.
  2. The more information you give, the easier it will be to track down the issue and fix it.
  3. Include Ruby, Rails and Figaro versions. Here's a little table to help you out:

```
|        | Version |
| ------ |---------|
| Ruby   | 2.1.1   |
| Rails  | 4.1.0   |
| Figaro | 1.0.0   |
```

This will render as:

|  | Version |
| --- | --- |
| Ruby | 2.1.1 |
| Rails | 4.1.0 |
| Figaro | 1.0.0 |
- When contributing
  - Maybe link to [GitHub's help page on pull requests](https://help.github.com/articles/creating-a-pull-request).
  - Link to [these guidelines](http://tbaggery.com/2008/04/19/a-note-about-git-commit-messages.html) for writing commit messages. This is the de facto standard, and I see links to it all the time.
  - Maybe reference the branch where pull requests should be sent to? I'd say most libraries use master by default (and GitHub does send pull requests to master by default) but I remember that that threw me off the first time I sent a pull request.
  - Mention tests?
Thoughts on [this](https://github.com/laserlemon/figaro/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)?

Are you using Capistrano for deployment? Usually, a new deployment will clobber the existing deployed code and replace it with a new checkout. The standard way to persist configuration files is to hook into your deployment process after a newly deployed checkout and symlink your configuration files from a safe location.

See the [`:symlink_shared`](http://railscasts.com/episodes/133-capistrano-tasks) task in this old Railscast.

I'm not sure that loading Figaro at the top of `application.rb` is wise or possible. In a Rails application, Figaro depends on `Rails.root` to find `config/application.yml`. If Figaro is loaded before `Rails.root` is defined in Rails' boot process, you'll see the `RailsNotInitialized` error.

I don't think that there's anything special about `application.rb` that would prevent these configurations from being set in initializers instead.

I'm closing this issue until we can gather more evidence that loading Figaro before or during evaluation of `application.rb` is a necessity. Thank you!

(I don't know the lifecycle well enough to say if there's some other way.)

One of them ensures expensive data structure is present in the cache. There are certainly other ways to achieve that, to be fair. I just thought that it would be somewhat common for initializers to use the cache in some way.

If that configuration file is loaded in an initializer, Figaro should have already loaded and your configuration variables should be available.

Have you tried need noisy log messages upon consumption?  When consuming a value from Figaro, say in an initializer, you could log an error message if a required key is missing. Or depending on usage it might be justified to have it raise an exception and halt.

Rails Example:

```
# config/initializers/airbrake.rb
if Figaro.env.airbrake_api_key?
  Airbrake.configure do |config|
    config.api_key = Figaro.env.airbrake_api_key
  end
else
  Rails.logger.warn "** AIRBRAKE_API_KEY was not set. **"
  # Or raise some exception.
end
```

@dlguage

I used to use nested config structures. We used our own internal gem that rolled yaml files such as your example into a nested structure of OpenStructs, deep-merging the default cofiguration with environment overrides that could also be nested.

Over time however I came to view this as anti-productive. In large apps the configuration files actually started to become too big to navigate a nested structure quickly. Also, when I was adding a new setting it was not always clear where in the structure it belonged so I would spend a little bit of time figuring it out, using up some of my decision-making-energy uselessly. 

Now I view the flat configuration file as more productive.

While I'd love for Figaro to work out of the box with Sinatra, I don't think this should be cause for surprise. The description of Figaro on GitHub and RubyGems is:

> Simple Rails app configuration

That said, work has begun in master to make Figaro less Rails-dependent. Please take a look at the progress made since the 0.7.0 release and please feel free to contribute with specific issues or pull requests.

Also, those aren't dark clouds you see! I'm excited about the changes being made to Rails. The original intent behind Figaro was to become part of Rails.

This isn't the intended use case for Figaro. The `application.yml` file should not be committed to the repo. Consider committing an `application.example.yml` or document your sensible defaults elsewhere. This allows `application.yml` to be used however you'd like.

Typically, I exclude a key from my `application.yml` if I don't want it set, rather than explicitly setting it to `nil`. I'm happy to have a conversation about the merits of explicitly setting `nil` values. Immediately, I don't see a the necessity because if a key is already present in `ENV` at Figaro load time, that key is ignored. This allows things like:

``` bash
some_key_to_override=some_value rails server
```

So the only keys that Figaro is allowed to set to `nil` would be keys that are already `nil`. Does that make sense? I might be missing something. Thanks!
I'll also say that the original intent of the boolean methods is to avoid no-method errors due to mistakenly omitted keys, not to test the nature (presence) of the set value itself.

Key set to nil in `application.yml` serves as good documentation. I can set specific values in environments. For example I dont' want to set `SIDEKIQ_PASSWORD` to any value on development.

Why not just allow for overwriting keys set to `nil` instead of ignoring them?

For example when I deploy to production and I see such `application.yml`:

```
SIDEKIQ_PASSWORD: ~
```

I know I need to create appropriate overrides for this value.

About avoiding unspecified values I think this is good case.

For example with following application.yml:

```
SIDEKIQ_PASSWORD: ~
```

figaro would fail at the deploy time (during `rails server` call), and not runtime. That's because it's clearly specified that `SIDEKIQ_PASSWORD` is nil and needs to be filled in. Do you understand what I mean?
This would also solve #75 without introducing new API.

I'm having a hard time following. Are you suggesting that nil values would be useful in the top level of `application.yml` like:

``` yaml
secret_key_base: "ccac4a50d952ce76e091ce675b642d4eac2fb102fe3ea632405cf2b85cdd23af"
sidekiq_password: ~
```

so that a developer seeing this file would know that `sidekiq_password` is a valid key and may be required in production?

I don't know that this solves #75 though because if the application is written in such a way that `sidekiq_password` is optional in development, it should also technically be optional in production. If a nil `sidekiq_password` value shouldn't fail on boot in development, it shouldn't fail on boot in production either.

I agree with your point that nil values can be useful for documentation. Also, in an `application.yml` file like:

``` yaml
sidekiq_password: "secret"
development:
  sidekiq_password: ~
```

nil values allow the default `sidekiq_password` to become nil in development. That also seems useful.

Beyond that, I think that when Figaro loads, nil values must simply be skipped over rather than clearing existing ENV values or raising an error.
You are right that right now `master` casts nil values to strings (I think) and that shouldn't be the case. Nil values should be skipped rather than cast to empty strings and set.

I like setting true/false flags.  Given the fact that both `"true"` and `"false"` are truthy, nil becomes the default false.  But I can't override a default truthy with nil.

This is a problem in my test env.  My test env runs `rake parallel:spec` which executes the development env and loads the test env.  Subsequently, I can't use figaro to override the development truthies with test nils.

application.yml:

``` yaml
development:
  enable_butts: true
test:
  enable_butts: nil
```

would be helpful rather than using the current workaround

``` ruby
so_many_butts if ENV['enable_butts'] == 'true'
```

+1 another reason for allowing nils:

In ENV empty string means nil, empty string is not expressible (good thing)

I guess this can be achieved by using something like [presence](http://apidock.com/rails/Object/presence) from Active Support for reading:

Pseudocode:

```
def Figaro.env(name)
  ENV[name.tos].presence
end
```
It's good thing because it makes unset values in ENV and values set to empty string semantically equivalent.
I'm a little against making empty string and nil being semantically equivalent because it breaks the assumption that `ENV['butts'] == Figaro.env.butts`
and/or if that's a change, it's definitely a breaking change which I'm okay with.
And I think every developer already uses something `blank?` for boolean tests, so nothing should practically break, only edge cases, but that's what 1.0 is for.

I will see what I can do to allow `nil` values to be set from `application.yml` but I don't believe it will be wise to make any special accommodations for blank strings. Blank strings are values and the boolean methods on `Figaro.env` will continue to report them as existing.

``` ruby
Figaro.env.foo # => ""
Figaro.env.foo? # => true
Figaro.env.foo! # => ""
```

Thank you!
The boolean methods on `Figaro.env` weren't added until after version 0.7 was released and those features are targeting version 1.0 as they'll be a breaking change. Thank you.

@laserlemon About case-insensitive env access:

> Environment variable names used by the utilities in the Shell and Utilities volume of IEEE Std 1003.1-2001 consist solely of uppercase letters, digits, and the '_' (underscore)

EDIT: on the other hand standard allows for lowercase letters..

I definitely agree with your arguments. I never believed this new feature to be a Figaro killer (just think of that cute mascot!). In fact, Figaro remains a strong gem choice because:
- Rails' approach does not use ENV variables.
- The `secrets.yml` file isn't automatically added to `.gitignore` (and it shouldn't, since clueless developers would deploy their apps to production without that file).

So at this point, I don't think Figaro really needs to change for Rails 4.1 . I, for one, will keep using Figaro.

I'll take a look at it, but I fear that we'll probably end up using our own fork moving forward because I don't think Thor is very good (I have had nothing but bad experiences with apps that use it, and trying to maintain Thor executables is IMO worse than writing something from scratch).

We've done a couple of things in a local `lib/tasks/figaro.rake`:

``` ruby
task 'figaro:heroku' => 'config:decrypt' # This decrypts our application.yml.gpg
task 'figaro:heroku' => 'figaro:app'

namespace :figaro do
  task :app, [ :app ] do |_, args|
    %w(raw yaml).each { |var|
      Figaro.instance_variable_set(:"@#{var}", nil)
    }
    $heroku_app = args[:app]
  end
end
```

The first added dependency (`config:decrypt`) is the main piece we can't live without that doing with Thor makes difficult. We want to force a decryption of our `application.yml.gpg` prior to pushing to heroku.

The second (`figaro:app`) is something that I think that Figaro could do as well, but I haven't made the changes for that locally (it would require bigger changes to the code and a local version of the Figaro gem; I was able to implement the diff/show capabilities inline to our `lib/tasks/figaro.rake` file. We use it like:

``` yaml
staging-app-1: &staging-app-1
  â€¦

staging-app-2: &staging-app-2
  â€¦

staging: &staging
  <<: *<%= $heroku_app || 'staging-app-1' %>
  â€¦
```

This lets us have multiple staging environments without changing the Rails environment code (it still uses `staging`, but incorporates either `staging-app-1` or `staging-app-2` as provided, defaulting to `staging-app-1`). The caching of `@raw` and `@yaml` in Figaro is a problem here as you've already initialized Figaro to `development` by running `rake` at allâ€”but clearing those values makes it work perfectly (and implementing the diff/show capabilities showed me that I needed to do that, because the diffs were much larger than they should have been).

(This is definitely advanced YAML, but once you understand it, it's pretty damned amazing.)

@jfelchner you should definitely look at the ref/deref capabilities of YAML and highlight them in [chamber](https://github.com/m5rk/chamber) documentation the way that I've shown above.

I'm working on getting 1.0 out the door and would like to bring this in but will have to think a bit more about _where_ it was implemented (Rails application vs. generic application) as well as the variable name. When Figaro sets ENV variables, it also sets a "FIGARO_" prefixed version to track what it has set. As is, this name could collide.

I like this idea but am still hung up on implementation. Version 1.0 includes the ability to swap out an "adapter." The only adapter built into the library is the Rails application adapter but one could extend Figaro to establish a different convention for Sinatra or another framework. To build in a `ENV["FIGARO_PATH"]` override, future adapter authors would need to be mindful to include the same override unless we come up with another way/place to override the path.
Could we talk about the merits of symlinking application.rb during deployment, rather than relying on Figaro to find the file elsewhere? Thoughts?

### Pros:
- no need have ENV var that might collide with some of the ENVs used by adapters, etc.
- keeps the convention that there's only one file (application.yml) that is being used by figaro gem

### Cons:
- need separate rules in config automation systems (i.e. Chef, Puppet) - might be cumbersome to set-up
- reliance on a filename convention is bad because it might collide with other gems
- some deployment systems might require re-running config after the deploy (imagine deploying with Capistrano that will create a new dir to store latest version of the app, but you use Puppet for the config -> You will have to re-run Puppet config after each deploy for no reason) -- @jbussdieker might have a few good points here

Also, wrt:

> To build in a ENV["FIGARO_PATH"] override, future adapter authors would need to be mindful to include the same override unless we come up with another way/place to override the path.

I don't think your statement justifies the argument against having highly customizable configuration library. To me it looks a like sacrifice worth making. Especially that there aren't any known additional adapters (apart from the built-in Rails one) that would have to use `ENV["FIGARO_PATH"]` and couldn't use something else.

Out of all the libraries out there figaro made most sense to us. The only obstacle was the need for storing config in application.yml in the app's folder. So we forked it 5 months ago and it worked like a charm. Maybe our use case was too specific to justify the code change, but on the other hand I don't see the need to overthink the problem: it's a very lightweight library, not Rails.

The problem that simply symlinking does not solve is that it mixes application config and application code. You are prevented from running 2 instances of a rails app from the same location with 2 different configurations. I want to be able to deploy a single copy of my code to a machine, and run the rails instance in different configurations on different ports:

```
$ /opt/deploy/my-app/rails server -p 3001 -e production --figaro /var/deploy/feature_a.rb
$ /opt/deploy/my-app/rails server -p 3002 -e production --figaro /var/deploy/feature_b.rb
```

With symlinking this is not possible.

@marcomorain: Is it possible to run two instances of an application on the same server so that each of them consume a different `ENV["FIGARO_PATH"]` value? If that variable is set at the server level, how can the value differ between the two application instances?
Yup, should work fine â€“ you can set env vars per process

It seems like the feature could still be a source of confusion when shelling into the server to fire up `rails console` or running migrations via Capistrano. If Figaro's configuration is only present in the one process, there's a lot of potential for surprise/failure outside of that process.

Also, if the application's configuration is to be kept outside of application root and only loaded into processes as determined by the server, this doesn't seem to be a job for the application code anymore. Rather than setting a `FIGARO_PATH` variable, the server could instead set the necessary configuration variables directly. Of course, you're still faced with the same challenge of loading those variables into any ancillary processes.
Figaro is moving this direction in an effort to be framework-indifferent. Leaving open for hopeful inclusion in 1.0.

In current master, you can avoid loading Rails by using a generic backend application, specifying the environment and path for the configuration file:

``` ruby
Figaro.application = Figaro::Application.new(environment: "production", path: "/path/to/application.yml")
Figaro.load
```

In case anyone else stumbles across this.  you just need the following in your Capfile

``` ruby
# Load ENV vars via Figaro
require 'figaro'
Figaro.application = Figaro::Application.new(environment: 'production', path: File.expand_path('../config/application.yml', __FILE__))
Figaro.load
```

Thank you! This is a known issue. We use Rails' standard hooks to initialize Figaro before Rails initializes. Unfortunately, this hook apparently occurs after `database.yml` is read. Trying to circumvent the standard hooks and tie into Rails' initialization elsewhere introduces a host of new problems and makes it very difficult to account for every situation in which the Rails environment is loaded.

I'm afraid this falls into the "won't fix" bucket until Rails provides a better (and supported) hook that Figaro can tie into. In my apps, I Git-ignore `database.yml` like I ignore `application.yml`. Not ideal, but it seems like the best we can do for now. Please feel free to investigate possible solutions yourself, as I'd love for Figaro to work as you expected. In the meantime, I'll close this issue. Thank you for the report! :clap:

Thank you for your code but this pull request may be misleading, giving people the mistaken impression that `ENV` will store array values. All `ENV` values must be strings.

By putting an array in `application.yml`, you're effectively setting your configuration value to the result of `Array#to_s` (which has been known to change its behavior between Ruby versions).

Configuration values should be explicit. So if you want your roles' value to be the exact string: `[admin, user, VIP]`, your YAML should read:

``` yaml
ADMIN_NAME: "Danny Van Hoof"
ROLES: "[admin, user, VIP]"
```

Does that address your issue? Thank you again for your contribution!

The vast majority of users use a UNIX Bourne shell, for which Ruby's `Shellwords` module was written. I guess you use a dynamic `database.yml` using `ENV`, as the one generated by Heroku. With a standard `database.yml`, as the one generated by `rails new app_name`, I think this problem does not appear.

However, I just had a similar problem on a different subject: I define the S3 bucket I use for [CarrierWave](https://github.com/carrierwaveuploader/carrierwave) in `config/initializers/carrier_wave.rb`. If I use the figaro way of defining an environment specific configuration, my test are run against my development bucket.

Apparently (at least with Rails 3.2), when you run `rake test`, the code in initializers is executed twice(!), the first time with `Rails.env == 'development'`, and the second time with `Rails.env == 'test'`. Both times Figaro gives the development value.

I guess this is a rather serious issue as it can lead to data loss. **I would recommend to make an immediate update to  `README.md`, mentionning that the environment specific configuration feature should not be used with `test` environment as it does not ensure (because of Rails) that default or development value is not used.**

After doing quite a bit of digging into Rails internals, I think this falls under the "won't fix" category. Figaro's configuration ties into Rails' initialization process in a very standard way that apparently will not occur before the database is configured and connected. Monkey-patching Rails to make this work automatically will not be very maintainable across the multiple versions of Rails that Figaro works with, and it strays from Figaro's credo of simplicity.

That said, there is still a lot about the Rails and Active Record initialization process that I don't fully understand and there may still be an elegant and reliable way to solve this issue. If that ends up being the case, I would gladly merge a simple pull request.

I hope that helps explain the situation and please do feel free to investigate!

I'll add that while keeping database configuration in `application.yml` seems nice on the surface, I personally keep `database.yml` separated from `application.yml`. `database.yml` isn't going away any time soon, so I figure I might as well use it. It's a strong convention.

@laserlemon As @eric-smartlove suggested, I think you should definitely mention in the README that _the environment specific configuration feature should not be used with test environment as it does not ensure (because of Rails) that default or development value is not used_.
Hi again! It turns out this is not `figaro`'s fault... I completely removed `figaro` from my app and I'm still getting my development database dropped when I run `rake spec`

Interesting. Might you have `DB_NAME` set in your local environment? In some further investigation, it looks like when you run `rake spec`, the Rails app is booted/initialized twice. The first time, Figaro is set up using the development environment. The second time, it's set up using test _but_ since the `ENV` vars are already set, they're not overwritten by Figaro.

It's very difficult to differentiate times when `ENV` is set explicitly vs. these types of scenarios.

Some tasks included in `rake spec` are run in the development environment, like `db:test:prepare` or `db:test:purge`. I think every task in the `:test` namespace should be run in the `test` environment, so I would consider this a bug in `rails`.

@deivid-rodriguez I don't know the exact status of this behavior (bug, wontfix or feature) but, as far a I know, it's an old and well-known Rails behaviour. I wouldn't expect that it will change anytime soon.

It _might_ be possible, but it'll be tricky. The problem is that Figaro will respect `ENV` vars that you pass in manually, like:


To accomplish that, we did [this](https://github.com/laserlemon/figaro/blob/6f6c31cdc6fc373d2ccb1f8481e52ede1583548a/lib/figaro/railtie.rb#L8).

So when Figaro is initialized _twice_, every key is ignored on the second run, unless we can find a reliable way for Figaro to track what it has set itself, and what was preexisting.

The problem with `application.example.yml` is that your local setup then quickly falls out of date. I imagine we all add some form of the following to our `bin/setup`

``` rb
  unless File.exist?("config/application.yml")
    system "cp config/application.yml.example config/application.yml"
  end
```

Which is great for a first install, but then you have to manually pull in changes from the example config forever forwards.

Alternatively, we could ignore `application.local.yml` and encourage people to check in `application.yml` as their "default values". No project setup required, the onus is now on environments which want to add overrides.

Hey all, I'm currently working on a 1.0 release of Figaro. Part of that effort is to make Figaro more easily extensible so that it could be used in other Ruby frameworks down the road. I'm also interested in revamping the rake tasks.

As it is now, rake tasks are clumsy when it comes to passing arguments. I'm considering using Thor tasks instead.

``` bash
figaro heroku:push --environment=staging
```

But with Thor, I'm having a hard time writing namespaces tasks like this, and there's the issue of loading the Rails environment first (or avoiding the need). Eventually, I'd like to see a few tasks:

``` bash
figaro heroku:push # Push Figaro configuration up to Heroku
figaro heroku:pull # Pull configuration down from Heroku into Figaro
figaro travis:encrypt # Encrypt Figaro configuration to Travis configuration
```

Any help, advice, code toward this would be great. Thanks for all of your insight thus far!

Argument passing could easily be solved using ruby's [OptionParser](http://ruby-doc.org/stdlib-2.0.0/libdoc/optparse/rdoc/OptionParser.html). But this way, you'd have to create an executable, not a rake task, I believe.

I actually searched for differences between executables and rake tasks. I wanted to understand the advantages one approach has over the other but I could not find anything. Is there something inherently bad with executables?

I don't think there's anything "bad" about executables. I think I'd prefer executables. That said, I'd like for the tasks to be self-contained enough that it should be easy to instantiate the task from an executable (Thor) or from a rake task.

Ok, so I dug a little deeper and was disappointed to find out that ruby's OptionParser does not have support for subcommands such as `heroku:push`. At least with that colon-separated syntax you wanted.

And as it happens, I don't think Thor supports that syntax as well. There's a [hackish way to do it](http://stackoverflow.com/a/5932034/1160916) though.

Iâ€™m open to alternative syntaxes (although I do like the colon separated). Is there any way that the â€œheroku:pushâ€ portion could actually be an argument and we could switch based on that? Just thinking out loud.

```
end
```

Interesting! I wonder which should have precedence across a wider sampling of use cases. Thanks for bringing this up.

As far as I know not possible to distinguish between ENV vars defined in the local env and the ones explictly passed into a command, so it's ALL ENV-vars overwrite the ones from application.yml or none...

However I like the Idea of ENV-vars overwriting the ones from application.yml. In my opinion precedence should be like this:

```
(default value <) application.yml < ENV
```

If Figaro then overwrites with values from ENV but **only if it's not an empty string** you can still do `UNWANTED_VAR= rails server` to get rid of unwanted vars in your ENV.
I really like @mhutter thoughts on this, it would have been my expected behavior too.

Another alternative that would achieve similar flexibility (and help teams work together) would be the ability to load another .yml file after the application.yml. That way, everyone could have their own .gitignore'd personal .yml files without needing to edit the main application.yml.
Good point, made me think of how [pow does the same thing](http://pow.cx/manual.html#section_2.2) with `.powrc` and `.powenv`.
What is the reason of an `application.yml` config if you check it in your repository? That way, you could as well hardcode the values into your code... `application.yml` belongs in your `.gitignore`!

@HALapeno that is what Foreman (and dotnev) do:

```
$ unset FOO

$ cat foo.env
FOO: 123

$ ruby -rrubygems -e "require 'dotenv'; p ENV['FOO']; Dotenv.load('foo.env'); p ENV['FOO']"
nil
"123"

$ FOO=bar ruby -rrubygems -e "require 'dotenv'; p ENV['FOO']; Dotenv.load('foo.env'); p ENV['FOO']"
"bar"
"bar"
```

+1
I just ran into this as well... I'd like to supply reasonable defaults in an `application.yml.example` (we don't check in an `application.yml`) but allow developers to override values explicitly at the command line _or_ in another higher-precedence file, such as `application.local.yml`.

Our team checks in the `application.yml` file since all our projects are on private repos. I've read in several places that you shouldn't check that file in, but I guess we don't see the harm in doing that instead of having a `application.yml.example` if the repo is private.

I agree with @joeyAghion, an `application.local.yml` file (or something similar) that is .gitignored and merges on top of the environment variables from `application.yml` would be a very nice addition. I think for now though I'll just hack it in with a `before_configuration` block.

You raise a good point that there's no real reason (that I know of) that convention has been uppercase `ENV` variables. That said, this seems to be purely a matter of personal taste and there's nothing preventing you from using lowercase configurations in `application.yml`,

``` yaml
foo: "bar"
```

and in your code.

``` ruby
ENV["foo"]
```

This brings up a good question

Looking at the **lib/figaro/env.rb** - https://github.com/laserlemon/figaro/blob/master/lib/figaro/env.rb#L7-L9

``` ruby
def method_missing(method, *)
    ENV.fetch(method.to_s.upcase) { super }
end
```

It expects your keys to be up-case, not patching this means you are bound to have up-case keys in the configuration file if you want to use the nice methods on the figaro env, like so:

``` ruby
Figaro.env.foo
```

Okay, I think I got it. It seems like your `application.yml` must have a `false` value in it. Those aren't allowed in `application.yml` because `ENV` is only capable of storing string/string key/value pairs. I'll work on a "fix" for this, although, it's only going to case `false` to `"false"`, so look out if you're depending on its falsiness.

Delayed Job using yaml is Delayed Job's fault. ENV is one-level key-value, you can't have nested properties so using tmop it's overcomplication for me. And yaml has support in many stdlibs.

Seriously I see no point in such feature.

I understand that YAML has far more features than Figaro needs and this makes it problematic. For example, many bugfixes are about escaping values which are special in YAML. But Rails is an opinionated framework and they have chosen YAML for configuration needs. It is a convention. As long as `figaro.gemspec` includes line `gem.add_dependency "rails"`, YAML should be supported. And I see no any big win in adding support for an additional format which gives no real advantages. After all, those are nearly flat, clean-looking configs which are seldom edited.

If someone has very custom needs in configuration format and really cares about that, then most probably Figaro is not for him for other reasons too. It isn't well suited for storing binaries, data structures and so on. He'll write his own solution from scratch.

I did not take away from @qrush's post that storing configurations in YAML files is bad in itself. Because of the nature of this attack (remote execution), the attacker could have just as easily inspected `ENV` and thrown that into Pastie. Your app processes need access to your configuration, so if an attacker has access to those processes, it really doesn't matter how you're storing your configs.

If the concern were some vulnerability giving an attacker access to the filesystem rather than the Ruby process, then yes, Figaro's `application.yml` file would be a less secure option.

That said, what's great about Figaro is that if you prefer to throw your configs into your server's `ENV` rather than `application.yml`, that'll work perfectly fine.

I hope that makes sense and maybe even helps. Feel free to continue the conversation here, although I will close the issue.

In case anyone's still interested I got it to work in my Rails 2.3.18 (patched 2.3.11) app.

```
require 'figaro/rails/application'
Figaro.adapter = Figaro::Rails::Application
Figaro.load
```

The Ruby `Kernel.system` method (http://www.ruby-doc.org/core-1.9.3/Kernel.html#method-i-system) does not return the standard out of the executed command, but rather returns true or false based on whether the given command was successfully executed.  Therefore, the previous code was not going to work as it attempted to assigned `true` to `Rails.env`.

I've updated the code to use the `Kernel.`` (backtick) operator instead.  This method will return the standard output.

Also, I've moved the code from the rake task into its own class to ease testing.

Please note that my first commit broke the Travis CI build because I was using the Ruby 1.9 style `Hash` syntax.  In my second commit I revert to the 1.8 style syntax.  The build is still broken, but the issue appears to be related to bundler not being able to execute in the Travis CI environment due to a timeout issues (see the error below). `ENV` is only a string-to-string key/value store. There's no way for `ENV` to store arrays as values, even though YAML can.

Building further on Daniel's solution, I slightly rewrote `vars`, which seems to solve the problem of both the spaces and the arrays. Hope you can approve the modification:

``` ruby
module Figaro
  module Tasks
    class Heroku # < Struct.new(:app)
      def vars
        #Figaro.vars(environment)
        Figaro.env(environment).map { |key, value|
          "'#{key}=#{value.gsub('"', '')}'"
        }.sort.join(" ")
      end
    end
  end
end
```

I think one of us is missing something. Putting `ENV` variables in `application.yml` is redundant because all Figaro is gonna do is pull them intoâ€¦ `ENV`. So you could just leave them out of `application.yml` and you'd be good to go! Does that make sense?

Yes and no. While you're completely correct, I'm working on an open-source project. And I prefer to have as little "behind-the-scenes" magic going on as possible, if that makes sense. 

While I'm only using `ENV` stuff for ERB in my file, you could be executing arbitrary Ruby code. I think there are plenty of use cases, and it's not really hurting anything being in there, unless you think otherwise.

Like... consider this:

``` yaml
SECURITY_KEY: <%= `openssl rand -hex 24` %>
```

This would give you a unique security key, each time the app starts, but it's consistent across each session of the app.

I think your example would be better served in an initializer:

``` ruby
ENV['SECURITY_KEY'] = `openssl rand -hex 24`
```

The use case I have for this pull request is as follows (unless of course someone can suggest a better way of structuring my config?)

My example application currently uses `sqlite3` - it's a noddy little application. Convention is that `sqlite3` files are found in `db/`:

```
$ ls -1 db/*.sqlite3
db/development.sqlite3
db/production.sqlite3
db/test.sqlite3
```

Now I currently deploy my application to [OpenShift](https://openshift.redhat.com). But OpenShift's deployment blows away the entire repo every time you `git push`. Files that must persist need be stored in `$OPENSHIFT_DATA_DIR` which is outside the repo tree.

In order to not have OpenShift specific `ENV['OPENSHIFT_XYZ']` references kicking around my code, the pattern I was hoping to use has the following structure:

``` yaml
# config/application.yml

PRODUCTION_DATABASE_DIR: <%= ENV['OPENSHIFT_DATA_DIR'] %>
```

``` yaml
# config/database.yml

production:
  adapter: sqlite3
  pool: 5
  timeout: 5000
  database: <%= ENV['PRODUCTION_DATABASE_DIR'] %>/production.sqlite3
```

This way, if I ever move to Heroku or CloudFoundry, the number of required changes is limited to 1 file (theoretically at least... there might well be other tweaks required).

Does this make sense? 

Or can someone suggest an alternative?

Incidentally, @laserlemon I'm a big fan of `figaro` - it's helped to [tidy up my projects no end](http://blog.myitcv.org.uk/2013/03/10/using-figaro-and-bash-for-a-smoother-development-config-environment.html)

This makes a lot of sense to me and to be honest I don't know why @laserlemon wont add this simple line of code.

The approach of @sethvargo with the https://github.com/sethvargo/magiconf is also not bad but I like to keep it simple. https://github.com/laserlemon/figaro is clean and is just lacking this little feature.

Cheers

I believe my example fits with the pattern of figaro: 
- My `.gitignore` includes `config/application.yml`
- In development I set all of my variables via ENV variables
- In production, because I can't control the environment, I patch in missing `ENV` vars using figaro

That said, I'm certainly not averse to changing my pattern of working, but I like the pattern figaro supports.

@sethvargo I am not set against adding this functionality. I've just been taking time to consider the use cases. I don't want to add functionality that might encourage misuse of the library. Nor do I want to add a feature just for the sake of adding a feature.

My use case is using Pow with VMs.  We have several apps that work together, and need to know each other's URLs.  We put the URLs to the other applications in application.yml so that they become part of the environment.  I understand that this is not really how the library was intended to be used, but it's a nice library and we like the convenience of having everything in one place (several URLs from external vendors do have the credentials in the URL).

To finish how we use it, we commit an encrypted version of application.yml, so that the credentials are available to every member on the team (closed source project).  It's not a perfect system, but it works pretty well.  

At any rate, I am doing some script magic in .powrc to export a variable that lets me know if these apps should talk to each other at app.dev or at app.ip_adddress.xip.io.  (You use the latter form when hitting them from a VM).

If I could do ERB exansion, I could put a simple expression like:
    MASTER_URL: http://master.<%= ENV['POW_ADDR'] %>/
in my application.yml and be done.

I wish thinking there should be an option for Figaro to load in multiple `.yml` files. That way, I can store something like `config.yml` in revision control while `application.yml` contains my sensitive stuff and will be created manually on production. The API could possibly look like

``` ruby
Figaro.configure do |config|
  config.files = %w(application.yml config.yml)
end
```

Thoughts? Would you accept a pull request for this?

The problem with configuring Figaro is that it's kind ofâ€¦ too late. By the time the initializers run, Figaro's already done! That's what allows us to use Figaro-set configurations in other initializers. I would encourage you to set these in your own public, committed Ruby file or add them to `application.yml`. You could also roll your own solution (in `application.rb` to load in a `config.yml` file:

``` ruby
config_path = File.expand_path('../config/config.yml', __FILE__)
ENV.update(YAML.load_file(config_path)) if File.exist?(config_path)
```

What about a `.figaro` file? Just to keep things DRY and also take advantage of the environmental logic that's already built into Figaro.

```
application.yml
config.yml
```

Seems that having two configuration files _would_ be repeating yourself, when the job can be done with one. In the past, I've committed an `application.example.yml` and that can include all sorts of content and comments regarding what values can stay and which still need to be added.

The two config files would have different roles. For example, `application.yml` would look like

``` yaml
SENDGRID_API_KEY: abcdefg

development:
    DATABASE_PASSWORD: yomomma

production: 
    DATABASE_PASSWORD: yodadda
```

and then `config.yml` would look like

``` yaml
USER_LOGIN_MAX_ATTEMPTS: 5
USER_SIGNUP_ENABLED: true
CONTACT_EMAIL:  support@example.com
```

They really shouldn't overlap, although `application.yml` if defined first within `.figaro`, should take precedence.

``` ruby
puts ENV["USER_LOGIN_MAX_ATTEMPTS"]  # 5
```

The `application.example.yml` is still useful, but only for `application.yml` since it's not commited to the repository. Say you would like to change the login max attempts, it seems like it would make more sense to commit that to repo rather than go to each of your production servers and change it manually.
Thoughts? :smile:

This seems like unnecessary repetition.

By the way, instead of editing files directly on the server which aren't checked into version control, symlink them into a shared directory and use something like capistrano to upload the config. You can even have this run automatically every time you deploy.

``` ruby
after 'deploy:setup' do
  transfer :up, "config/application.yml", "#{shared_path}/application.yml", :via => :scp
end

before 'deploy:finalize_update' do
  run "ln -sf #{shared_path}/application.yml #{latest_release}/config/application.yml"
end
```
+1 for this. I often need to have shared and developer specific variables, having two configuration files would be good so I can check in the shared version.

Hi Maxwell,

Thanks for writing! I love the idea of loading in environment specific configs. I only have a couple concerns:

Determining the environment. While Figaro is currently built for Rails apps, there's nothing keeping it from being used for any old Rack app. This issue is certainly able to be overcome.

Next up: the difference between Figaro and Settingslogic is that Figaro's configs are _flat_. By that, I mean they'll be loaded into `ENV` which is just a collection of key/value pairs. Figaro doesn't support nested configs. So mashing the environment-specific configs into the top-level may be tricky. For instance:

``` yaml
airbrake_api_key: 932685345ee738a742210be4c2223864
development:
  host: example.local
production:
  host: example.com
```

In development, the mashed config would look something like:

``` yaml

airbrake_api_key: 932685345ee738a742210be4c2223864
host: example.local
production:
  host: example.com
```

Now that I'm writing this, I suppose Figaro could just ignore hash or array values post-mash.

Please feel free to take a stab at this. Just please don't be offended if I tweak for style! :smile: Otherwise, I can give it a shot when I'm able. Thanks again for the suggestion!

Roger about the nested hashes.  I guess a rather **simple** way to handle it, is any key that contains a hash would have to match the ENV (however you decide to try and detect that), and then would be deep merged on top of the top level hash.

For example:

``` yaml
airbrake_api_key: 932685345ee738a742210be4c2223864
development:
  host: example.local
production:
  host: example.com
```

would become, in 'production':

``` yaml
airbrake_api_key: 932685345ee738a742210be4c2223864
host: example.com
```

but in enviroment 'foo' would be

``` yaml
airbrake_api_key: 932685345ee738a742210be4c2223864

```

EDIT: realized this is exactly what you said.  Brain moving slowly today.  If I take a stab, it would work like the above.

I realize that might not be the most magical solution, but it would work to suite my needs :P

Make perfect sense to me. As for the environment, it might be as simple as:

``` ruby
ENV["RAILS_ENV"] || ENV["RACK_ENV"]
```

As far as the magical solution, Figaro is intentionally non-magical. I thought that the added constants and pretty method chaining of other config solutions were overkill. So please avoid magic at all costs! :tophat: :rabbit: :gun:

Bob, thank you for the pull request! I'm actually working on this very thing myself. A couple things keep me from pulling this in.

First, _no tests_! Actually, that's what's keeping me from putting out my own work on this. I'm having a hard time writing solid, real-world tests for it.

Secondly, I'm not sure yet if it would be better to call `system` or use backticks rather than calling `Heroku::CLI` methods directly. In that case, I'd want to conditionally add the rake task based on `defined?(Heroku)`. Thoughts?

I just had this task around that I use sometimes and think it would be cool to have this kind of feature.. I'll do a little research later today and update.

Yes, I think it can be tested with Cucumber and Aruba. A scenario may look like:

``` cucumber
Given I add "heroku" as a dependency
And I bundle
And I run "bundle exec heroku apps:create"
And I create "config/application.yml" with:
  """
  HELLO: world
  """
When I run "bundle exec rake figaro:heroku"
Then the output should be:
  """
  Adding config vars and restarting app... done, v1
    HELLO => world
  """
```

This is how I started trying to test it and I planned on stubbing requests to the Heroku API using `webmock` but because the `heroku apps:create` call and the rake task are outside of the currently running Cucumber process, those stubbed requests are lost. :-1:

What I like about your approach is that it simply defers to a Heroku command and so it's much easier to assert that the proper command is run. My way, I could assert that the proper Heroku::CLI method is called with the proper arguments, but that is far more likely to change than the forward-facing interface.

Either way, without being able to access stubbed requests in the subprocesses that are fired up in the Cucumber context, this is feeling much more like a spec addition than a scenario.
