Hey! I love this suggestion ðŸ˜„ 

Would it be sufficient to simply say that you want a front-matter title as well when generating new daily pages? Or would you want to be able to specify the entire front-matter block? I just ask because I could probably add a setting to allow generating a front-matter section for new page, that simply auto-generated the title based on the date. But if you'd want to also add other content to the template, than we'd probably need another, more generic solution.

I would personally be more than happy with the first suggestion of generating a front-matter section with a title based on the date via a toggleable setting. This would make it practically frictionless to add new posts for my particular use case.

It would also be good to have a more generic solution, but this may be a bit more complex.

For instance, [Docusaurus's example post](https://docusaurus.io/docs/blog#adding-posts) has 9 separate fields:

```md
---
title: Welcome Docusaurus v2
author: Joel Marcey
author_title: Co-creator of Docusaurus 1
author_url: https://github.com/JoelMarcey
author_image_url: https://graph.facebook.com/611217057/picture/?height=200&width=200
tags: [hello, docusaurus-v2]
description: This is my first post on Docusaurus 2.
image: https://i.imgur.com/mErPwqL.png
hide_table_of_contents: false
---
```

Granted, it would be convenient to have certain static fields like `author`, `author_url`, `author_image_url`, and `hide_table_of_contents` automatically filled out for you when making a new post.

The generic solution would probably be more valuable to users that are making posts for a website with multiple writers or if there were repeating metadata when making new posts.

But again, it would be great to have the non-generic solution as well.

I wonder if it would make sense to allow adding a `DAILY_TEMPLATE.md` file to the repo, and specify whatever content you want in there. Then, whenever you create a new daily page, it would auto-populate the file with the contents from that template file.

In order to parameterize it, the template could support mustache placeholders (e.g. `{{foo}}`) that would be rendered properly whenever a page was created from it. To start, we could support a `{{title}}` placeholder, but we could add more over time. The nice thing about this solution, is that it would allow you to define the front-matter you want, but would also be quite a bit more flexible (and also interoperable with other note-taking solutions). It would also be similar to how GitHub enables issue/PR templates. Thoughts?

### Example `DAILY_TEMPLATE.md`

```
---
title: {{title}}
author: Joel Marcey
author_title: Co-creator of Docusaurus 1
author_url: https://github.com/JoelMarcey
author_image_url: https://graph.facebook.com/611217057/picture/?height=200&width=200
tags: [hello, docusaurus-v2]
description: This is my first post on Docusaurus 2.
image: https://i.imgur.com/mErPwqL.png
hide_table_of_contents: false
---
```

That sounds great, pretty much exactly what I would would want as a user, especially if the feature gains the ability to also add more mustache placeholders over time.

I feel like the solution is also flexible enough to cover a large amount of use cases, minimizing a lot of redundant busywork with the click of a button.

Hey! There's actually already a protocol handler for opening a repo, though it needs to be enhanced in order to make this E2E truly shine. If you launch `vscode://vsls-contrib.gistfs/open?repo=microsoft/vscode` from your browser, that would open the VS Code repo in VS Code. If you didn't have the GistPad extension installed, it would walk you through installing it and then would open the repo. So if you wanted to create a Chrome extension, you could rely on that URL convention right now.

That said, the current protocol handler automates opening the repo, but it doesn't focus the GistPad tab and scroll the newly opened repo into view. So we could use this issue to track some enhancements that I can make to that behavior. Let me know what you think!

I managed to link GistPad to the correct account by doing the following:

1. Log into GitHub as the incorrectly added account
2. In GitHub go to "Settings > Applications > Authorised OAuth Apps" and revoke the authorisation for GistPad.
3. LOG OUT of the incorrectly added Github account
3. In VScode, uninstall GistPad and relaunch VScode.
4. In VScode, reinstall GistPad 
5. Click on the notebook icon in VScode and authenticate GistPad against the correct GitHub account.

Hey! There's actually a setting you can use to overwrite the filename. It's called "gistPad.scratchNotes.fileFormat", and it takes a [Moment.Js format string](https://momentjs.com). To use the format you mentioned, you could set this to "YYYY-MM-DD". Let me know if that works for you!

There's also a setting called "GistPad.scratchNotes.directoryFormat" that you can use to group gists by year, or month. So for example, you could set that to "YYYY-MM", and it would group all of your scratch notes in a folder for the respective month.

I decided to look into this a little more, because I wanted to know why the change worked, and I am now not positive this is the right way to fix it. It may fix some, but I think the GIT_ASKPASS tool is the main problem. I don't know how to make it consistently prompt for username/password yet. VSCode's Git extension has a script that lets it return an empty string for the password if the credentials aren't set, `%LOCALAPPDATA%/Programs/Microsoft VS Code/resources/app/extensions/git/dist/askpass-empty.sh`, but I guess it depends if the prompt should happen or not.
I added details why in the issue: https://github.com/vsls-contrib/gistpad/issues/153#issuecomment-643555472

I think the disabled by default that you did is the way it should have been handled. The git credential tool itself seems a little buggy anyway, such as giving an input error when trying to use it in Powershell without a script. I didn't even know about `git credential store`, until debugging this, so some other tool must have set the one I had stored at some point, but I have no idea which one.

I cut my change down to just the attempt at setting the `askpass-empty.sh` script from the git extension, but it doesn't guarantee that someone hadn't configured theirs to work using one of the ways other than the environment var. Now that the feature is disabled by default, maybe it is fine to assume the ones that enable it, or at least enough that it won't keep getting reported, will already have set their credentials or at least know how. If it is fine to just assume users enabling it know what their doing or can figure it out, since the README does already say "when you've already authenticated with github.com", this PR can just be closed.

After looking into this more, I don't know if my pull request is the right way to fix it. My problem seems to be more about the `GIT_ASKPASS` tool. It looks like the `GIT_ASKPASS` environment var isn't correctly set to use VSCode and instead is getting hung waiting for the username/password prompt to be inputed.

First I wrote a small nodejs script to see if `execSync` and `execFileSync` were using the same Git.
```js
const { execSync, execFileSync } = require('child_process')

console.log('execFileSync: where git')
console.log(execFileSync('where', ['git'], { encoding: 'utf8' }))

console.log('execFileSync: where git.exe')
console.log(execFileSync('where', ['git.exe'], { encoding: 'utf8' }))

console.log('execFileSync: where git.bat')
console.log(execFileSync('where', ['git.bat'], { encoding: 'utf8' }))

console.log('execSync: where git')
console.log(execSync('where git', { encoding: 'utf8' }))

console.log('execSync: where git.exe')
console.log(execSync('where git.exe', { encoding: 'utf8' }))

console.log('execSync: where git.bat')
console.log(execSync('where git.bat', { encoding: 'utf8' }))
```
Output:
```txt
execFileSync: where git
E:\Programs\depot_tools\git.bat
C:\Program Files\Git\cmd\git.exe

execFileSync: where git.exe
C:\Program Files\Git\cmd\git.exe

execFileSync: where git.bat
E:\Programs\depot_tools\git.bat

execSync: where git
E:\Programs\depot_tools\git.bat
C:\Program Files\Git\cmd\git.exe

execSync: where git.exe
C:\Program Files\Git\cmd\git.exe

execSync: where git.bat
E:\Programs\depot_tools\git.bat
```

So, with that I can tell why changing `execSync` to `execFileSync` worked for me. I have github credentials in the windows git, but not the depot_tools git. (I shouldn't even have the depot_tools version even on my PATH anymore, but I haven't been having any problems, so I forgot it was there.) Since `execFileSync` doesn't spawn a shell it must be skipping over my first git tool(`git.bat`) on my PATH and using the second(`git.exe`), which already had credentials, so the prompt wasn't needed. The NodeJS docs explaining why `execFileSync` would skip the batch file are here: https://nodejs.org/api/child_process.html#child_process_spawning_bat_and_cmd_files_on_windows

Fixing the `GIT_ASKPASS` environment var to correctly use VSCode as its AskPass tool is what I am thinking the correct fix may be. I have got it to return an empty string if credentials don't exist using `%LOCALAPPDATA%/Programs/Microsoft VS Code/resources/app/extensions/git/dist/askpass-empty.sh` from VSCode's Git extension. If it should allow the prompt to work, I have got it to use VSCode as the AskPass tool, but I haven't figured out how to make it consistently use it correctly.

@Marklb Interesting! I was wondering why I couldn't repro this, and maybe it's because I don't have the `GIT_ASKPASS` env var set? Out of curiosity: did you set this manually? Or did some tool set this on your behalf?

@YusufMohammedUH By any chance, is the `GIT_ASKPASS` env var set for your as well? I'd love to narrow down whether this is the issue.

@lostintangent I am not sure what is actually being used when I call `execSync` from the extension. From what I remember the environments spawned from VSCode inherit some of the VSCode specific vars by default, but I don't remember where I read that, so I am not positive. I think I had read it on something explaining how some scripts executed in the embedded terminal will try to use VSCode for things like the EDITOR if one hasn't been specified, but its been a while since I read about it.
There are at least three places the AskPass tool can be configured, based on the documentation(https://git-scm.com/docs/gitcredentials#_requesting_credentials). Looks like it checks `GIT_ASKPASS` environment var first, then the git config `core.askPass`, then `SSH_ASKPASS` environment var, then terminal prompt if nothing else is found.

Should this extension be trying to make the username and password prompts work or just treating the store as readonly as far as this extension is concerned? It looks like the VSCode Git extension uses `GIT_ASKPASS`, `VSCODE_GIT_ASKPASS_NODE` and `VSCODE_GIT_ASKPASS_MAIN`, which may be why I was getting inconsistencies only setting the `GIT_ASKPASS` var. https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/git/src/askpass.ts#L75

I was doing a mix of trying from a nodejs script run from Powershell in VSCode, Powershell in Windows Terminal and the extension. Now I will try again and track what happens a little more organized, now that I know a little more about what is going on.

In the PR I switched back to `execSync`, so it should allow the `git.bat` file to work again, in case that did happen to be how I primarily execute git. I didn't get it to prompt for credentials, but it should at least return an empty string if the credentials aren't set, instead of hanging.

The environment vars being inherited must have just meant for the terminal. If I run a script in the VSCode terminal it has the environment vars `GIT_ASKPASS`, `VSCODE_GIT_ASKPASS_NODE`, `VSCODE_GIT_ASKPASS_MAIN`, and `VSCODE_GIT_IPC_HANDLE`, but in the extension `execSync` had none of those set. I tried setting them in the extensions `execSync` call, but it still didn't give me a login prompt.

Sorry you ran into this issue! Can you ensure you have â€œgnome-keyringâ€ and â€œlibsecretâ€ installed? When you sign-in with GistPad, it stores your GitHub token in the OS keychain, and therefore, requires those libs to be installed. On Windows/macOS, the OS already includes all the dependencies needed for GistPad to store/retrieve secure tokens, which is likely why you didnâ€™t have this problem on Windows.

Additionally, the Gist extension stores your token in VS Codeâ€™s extension storage (which isnâ€™t secure or encrypted), which is likely why it didnâ€™t have this problem on Linux either.

I call these dependencies out in the getting started docs, but I need to improve the error handling error ðŸ˜ VS Code is adding native GitHub auth soon, and so Iâ€™m excited for that to land, since it will improve the auth experience a lot.

Legend! Thanks for the quick response. :)

You've actually completely solved a use case I was thinking of about a year ago with these two extensions. Let me explain:

When learning from video tutorials, I figured out it was better to create my own notes rather than coding along with the video, and then do the projects from my own notes. It helped with retention and gave me something to refer back to, but was less time efficient due to double handling.

With GistPad/CodeTour though, it's a cake and eat it too deal. I can set up a tutorial for each course, and create a tutorial step for each video in the course (can simply duplicate the step once it's written then move onto the next one). Using CodeTour I'll write explanatory notes, and that way I've simultaneously coded the project and also written explanatory notes to refer back to, and in a really accessible format that doesn't require too much searching for what I'm after.

With either GistPad or CodeTour on their own, this wouldn't be that amazing. You could CodeTour a whole project but the tour would be impossible to manage or find anything. Likewise, the GistPad Tutorial Playgrounds on their own are great but each step can still be a whole video of content, which can be overwhelming and lacks a happy path.

Together though, in all seriousness, this functionality is an app that I would pay for. I expect it will decrease my learning time and increase my ability to execute my own projects afterward.

The fact that you can also export CodePens is serendipitous too since a lot of courses will have their first video using a CodePen to get people involved with the language before explaining how to set up a local dev environment later on.

Hey! Weâ€™re not doing any bundling in order to support modules. Weâ€™re simply setting the scriptâ€™s type attribute to â€œmoduleâ€. So if you import other modules, theyâ€™d need to either be 1) a relative URL to another file in the same gist, or 2) an absolute URL that points at a JS module (e.g. using a CDN like Unpkg). 

Right now, a playground determines if it should use modules based on the scriptType property in its way playground.json file. That said, I can also add supoort for .mjs files as well. Do you think that the JS-only module template should generate an .mjs file? Would that be the more accurate solution?

> Do you think that the JS-only module template should generate an .mjs file? Would that be the more accurate solution?

I'd personally find that more clear / easier to tell apart at first glance. But I think my primary concern would be that I  can safely rename it to `.mjs` without breaking the playground. If that is supposed to work, it could also be that I messed up at some point while trying out this plugin (which is great, btw!).
Sounds good. Iâ€™ll make this change so that when you create a new playground for a JS module, that it creates a â€œ.mjsâ€ file by default. Look out for that change later today ðŸ‘

I apologize, Iâ€™m still not entirely following you. Do you not want to see the gistâ€™s description in the tree at all? And would rather just see the file name if the gist only contained a single file? If you delete the gistâ€™s description, this is exactly what you would see. I just want to make sure I understand exactly what youâ€™re trying to optimize for (e.g. presentation, ergonomics, etc.) so that I can weigh that with other user preferences.

> And would rather just see the file name if the gist only contained a single file?

exactly

If you create a Gist right now, and donâ€™t set a description (the description is optional), then the name of the Gist will be the name of the single-file   in the gist. So you could get your desired experience using the current version of GistPad.

That said, are you saying that you want to have a description for the gist, but that the name of the file is more descriptive to you? Iâ€™m only asking because the description is optional, since itâ€™s meant to add more recognizable meaning to the files, _if_ the file name isnâ€™t itself already meaningful on its own (e.g. index.html doesnâ€™t mean anything without a description). So it seems like there are two potential solutions here:

1. People that want to see the file name vs. the description can simply not set a description when creating the gist. As I mentioned, this is the current behavior today

2. I could add a setting that allows users to choose between tree node label options, so they can control whether the gist node displays its description or the file name

#1 has the benefit of being config-free and responds to the userâ€™s intent (e.g. you didnâ€™t set a description, so you implicitly declared that you care more about the file name than the gist description). So it would be great to understand what your workflow looks like, and why youâ€™re setting a description, but donâ€™t want to actually see it.

Assuming #1 isnâ€™t sufficient because you want to set a description, but still see the node using its file name, then I think #2 is the only option, that doesnâ€™t force users into one specific opinion.

You should update this line to also check whether `react` is present in the `libraries` list. That way, you can have ` .js` file and include JSX in it, and we'll know to compile it with TypeScript: https://github.com/vsls-contrib/gistpad/blob/master/src/commands/playground.ts#L70. Otherwise, I don't want to always run a TS compile on every edit, for any arbitrary JS file.

Also, I think we should automatically include React if the playground's script file is `*.jsx` or `*.tsx`. That way, we fully optimize playgrounds for React scenarios, without the end-user having to touch the `playground.json` file at all.

After taking a quick look at your Gists, I wonder if it would be simpler to add a `Run in Terminal` command to the tree, that would allow you to select a file in a Gist, have it be transparently downloaded to a temp location, and then run it in the VS Code integrated terminal. That way you don't need to deal with local temp files simply to evaluate scripts in a gist. Thoughts?

@lostintangent Well things get tricky there because if you want to do debugging, etc. you need to set breakpoints and ideally within lines on a file, so it has to be in a reasonably stable location and be "opened" by vscode so it can be evaluated by extensions such as the powershell extension.

I envision a user setting that, rather than opening the file in the "ephemeral" state it gets opened today, when doing an open action, it first gets copied to a temp filesystem and then opened from there in vscode, and when saved and closed, re-uploaded.

So, same transparent download as you mentioned, but then opened in vscode. Saving back changes I guess would be a secondary priority, but it beats my current workflow if I need to debug of:

Hey! Thanks for the feedback! Currently, CodeSwing has the concept of "tutorials" which is a directory/repo that includes an ordered list of swings. When you define a tutorial, the swing preview will render a navigation bar above the current step, and allow the reader to easily work through them. As an example, you can check out this port of the [CSS Diner sample](https://github.com/lostintangent/css-diner).

That said, I'd love to hear more about your thoughts here, since I'd love to improve the experience. Also, if you have any ideas/examples of great tutorials for learning a framework/language, we could possible use those as the test case for the experience. Thanks!

Thanks for the feedback! My main motivation for this current behavior is that I wanted a way to create temporary swings to try an idea, but without switching contexts. So for example, if I'm working on a web app codebase and I want to quickly try something with the React API, I could do that, without opening a new window.

That said, I agree that the current experience is optimized for that kind of "scratch pad" workflow. Out of curiosity: for your use case, would you be interested in creating the swings within the currently opened workspace?

I'll also give some thought to how to easily allow opening the swing is a new window as well. Stay tuned!

I just shipped an update to the extension that makes the following changes:

1. `CodeSwing: New Scratch Swing...` command is renamed to `CodeSwing: New Swing...` to avoid confusion with the scratch language, and to prescribe the use of "temporary" swings as the main workflow
2. Added the new `CodeSwing: Save Current Swing As...` command, which allows you to save the opened swing in a specified directory. This pairs nicely with the previous addition, since you can quickly create new "temporary" swings and save them later if you want
3. Added a new `CodeSwing: New Swing in Directory...` command to create a new swing in a specified directory. This is just a shortcut for doing 1 and 2 at once, if you already know you want to create a swing in a specific location
4. Introduced a template MRU, so that when creating a new swing, the last 3 templates you used will show up at the top of the list
5. Introduced the `CodeSwing: New Swing From Last Template` command, that allows you to create a new swing, using the most recently used template
6. Introduced the `CodeSwing: Open Swing in New Window` command, that allows you to open swings in a new window
7. Fixed the template list, so that it's "sticky" when you're creating a new swing

That said, I believe that addresses all of the feedback from this issue ðŸ˜„  I'm going to close it as resolved, but please let me know if you have any feedback. Thanks!

Great, this UX feels pretty nice, thanks!!

One last detail would be to be able to do 6. for new swings, in a single step. I can think of two options for this:

A. An extension setting (could be default-off, if you think that users would more commonly want to start in the same window) to `Open all new swings in new windows`
B. New commands for opening the new swings in new windows eg. `New Swing In New Window...`

I ran in to a related issue when trying to `@import` or `@use` an external Sass file, and looking at the code I can offer that with Sass' `renderSync` method you'd need to use the `file` parameter rather than `data`, so as to give the compiler a file-path reference point for imports. I would imagine a similar issue will exist for other language compilers

https://github.com/codespaces-contrib/codeswing/blob/197235fe5c0e5e72e6b9a3f4de2ba9f13d4a7376/src/preview/languages/stylesheet.ts#L37-L40

@lunelson Out of curiosity: are you trying to import a relative URL (another Sass file within the swing) or an HTTP-based URL? I just ask since HTTP-based imports should already work, since I believe Sass just passes them through to CSS.

@lostintangent actually I was trying to `@use` a Sass file (`@use` is Sass 4.x syntax, replacing `@import`) from outside of the codeswing. My hope was that an arrangement like this would work, so I could write swings under the `./test` directory of a Sass library that I'm developing, for example.

```
.
â”œâ”€â”€ _utils.scss
â”œâ”€â”€ utils.pug
â”œâ”€â”€ utils.js
â”œâ”€â”€ swing-a/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ script.js
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ codeswing.json
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ index.pug
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ style.scss
â””â”€â”€ swing-b/
    â”œâ”€â”€ script.js
    â”œâ”€â”€ codeswing.json
    â”œâ”€â”€ index.pug
    â””â”€â”€ style.scss
```

As an attempt to move forward, here is an option:
* When a new (JS) swing is generated, create a new `jsconfig.json` in the temp directory. I'm assuming this isn't difficult because other files (style.css, script.js, index.html) are generated so you just create it along with these.
* Populate the jsconfig.json file with:
```json
{
  "typeAcquisition": {
    "include": []
  }
}
```
* When a user selects a library, if they choose "latest", push the name of that library to `typeAquisition.include` then re-save file.
* This should trigger VSCode to download the types for that library.

I've been doing the above manually and it seems to work well. it's a quick win which gets you 90% of the way there. I couldn't see it being possible with the typescript plugin route.

Skypack have type declarations but you would need some sort of parser/crawler to bring them down. Typescript does not automatically fetch types from url-based imports, only Deno does this currently.

Just published the fix for this to the marketplace. The issue was exactly as you described ðŸ˜„  Thanks for reporting this!

The reason I went with `*` is because the logic for detecting a "swing" workspace is dynamic (e.g. other extensions can extend CodeSwing), and therefore, a static list of `workspaceContains` conditions wouldn't be entirely sufficient.

Additionally, CodeSwing exports an API for other extensions to use (e.g. [GistPad](https://aka.ms/GistPad)), and since there's no activation event for other extensions trying to use your API, these consumers would need to manually check if CodeSwing was activated, and if not, activate it. That's definitely not difficult to do, but I wanted to keep things simple since this extension is super new, and I'm exploring integrations with various folks.

Since the `onStartupFinished` event doesn't guarantee when it will be triggered, I was also a little hesitant to relying on it, since it could introduce seconds of latency when trying to open a swing workspace (depending on the extensions/etc. the user has). Once again, not the end of the world. But using `*` provides a couple of nice properties, that couldn't be fully emulated with other activation events.

Out of curiosity: are you seeing CodeSwing impact your startup time? Or did you just see the activation event in the extension details page? I'll do some profiling to see how to further streamline startup, since it should be pretty negligible. And I'll play around with `onStartupFinished` to see how it "feels" across different usage scenarios.

Just pushed an extension update that activates using `onStartupFinished`, when a command is run, or when a workspace is opened that contains a `codeswing.json` file at the root. Thanks for the feedback and let me know if you have any other feedback!

Regarding #1: which files do you want to be visible when you open a light swing? Just `index.ino`?I just ask since you mentioned `points.ts`, and I wanted to confirm if that was a file you expected users to edit, or if it was simply necessary for the built output. Regarding #2: would it be sufficient for now, to have the light swing extension declare an extension dependency on CodeSwing? As for the input system, "in production" my lights function off events that are sent to the devices. I emulated that with the input system... but the code editor view is far from ideal. I wonder if we could leverage the existing config support for your `points.ts` file? Right now, if your swing has a `config.json` file, I'll load that and inject it into the preview as `window.config`. Beyond that, I could add support for customizing the name of the config file, and defining that you want the config file displayed when opening the swing (both as settings in `codeswing.json`). That would allow you to call the swing `points.ts`, and have it be automatically opened when you open the swing.

Yup, your first set of errors appear to be due to a lack of public access to your albums, which means you'll indeed need to use an auth method, like that in `example-oauth.php` or `example-external-links.php`.

> Fatal error: Uncaught Error: Class 'phpSmug\Client' not found in

This error suggests the phpSmug client code can't be found. The most likely causes are:

- You've not installed phpSmug, or
- You're missing this line from the top of the example: `require_once 'vendor/autoload.php';`

As an aside, you might want to try testing and setting things up completely independently of another application like Wordpress. I regularly use [VSCode Remote Containers](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/remote/containers-tutorial) for such situations as it provides a clean reproducible environment unencumbered by other applications.  The samples in this repo work perfectly in the sample PHP container.

Hey there!

This is a great question, although at its core it's really a SmugMug API question that probably is best asked in the Digital Grin forum at https://dgrin.com/categories/smugmug-api-support-integrations or directly to the SmugMug API team at api@smugmug.com. This GitHub issue tracker is intended for reporting problems with phpSmug's functionality.

However, to get you started off, perhaps we can point you in the right direction.  You are correct that SmugMug's API for the _User_ endpoint doesn't have a (documented) way to list a user's folders. 

However, there is a _FolderList_ endpoint that will return a recursive list of all your folders. Here is a demonstration using SmugMug co-founder cmac's account because it already appears in the API documentation: https://api.smugmug.com/api/v2/folder/user/cmac!folderlist  (Replace 'cmac' with your own username.)

If you remove _!folderlist_ from the Uri, you can see the other data you can query from the _Folder_ endpoint: https://api.smugmug.com/api/v2/folder/user/cmac!folderlist

Please note that all the folder-related API endpoints are listed as depreciated and could disappear at anytime, which is unfortunate because they are useful.  In their absence, you would need to look up your username's Node ID and use the node-traversing endpoints. It would require many more API calls to sort through all the child nodes to find the folders, so I'm not sure why they are depreciating the useful functionality.

Regarding the missing albums, do they all appear correctly when you use the _UserAlbums_ endpoint on the live API browser?  Again, an example with cmac's data: https://api.smugmug.com/api/v2/user/cmac!albums

It may be that some of your albums are not being returned due _count_ and _start_ arguments, which control the size of returned data pages. On the live API browser, SmugMug limits responses to 10 objects per page. Of the top of my head, I'm not sure how they break up JSON responses.

Best wishes!
Daniel

@davidvexel, I believe that SmugMug folders, galleries, and pages are required to start with a number or a capital letter.

The on the live site, SmugMug site will rewrite HTTP requests for folders, galleries, and pages that start with a lowercase letter to make them start with uppercase.  However, the rest of the URL will still pay attention to case.

As such, _example.com/January-2019/wP-chico-local-test-smugmug-324_ will resolve to _example.com/January-2019/WP-chico-local-test-smugmug-324_ and display your gallery.  But _example.com/January-2019/wp-chico-local-test-smugmug-324_ will throw a 404 error.

I do not believe the API will correct for lowercase initial letters on requests.

Literally right after posting this I figured it out -- it's related to permissions on smugmug. If you're logged into smugmug the api requests send different information than they do to anonymous users. Thus browser (which is logged in) is getting info the server (not logged in) is not getting.

If anyone else runs into this, hope it helps.

its doesnt like the encoded "+" symbol you are doing...

This is where phpSmug is making your life easy and assumes you have no knowledge about encoding the params as there is no documentation that manual encoding is required within the SmugMug API docs.  

The API itself suggests manual encoding of options is _not_ required so phpSmug passes this on to you and expects you to use the options _exactly_ as they're returned by the API.

So in the case of ordering, the API supports the following (taken from the JSON from `https://api.smugmug.com/api/v2/user/{username}!albums#json`):

```json
"Parameters": {
    "GET": [
        {
            "Name": "Order",
            "Required": false,
            "ReadOnly": false,
            "Default": "",
            "Description": "Order Albums By",
            "Type": "Select",
            "OPTIONS": [
                "Album Settings",
                "Position",
                "Last Updated (Descending)",
                "Last Updated (Ascending)",
                "Date Added (Descending)",
                "Date Added (Ascending)"
            ],
            "MIN_COUNT": 1,
            "MAX_COUNT": 1
        },
        {
            "Name": "MinimumImages",
            "Required": false,
            "ReadOnly": false,
            "Default": 0,
            "Type": "Integer",
            "MIN_VALUE": 0,
            "MAX_VALUE": 16777215
        }
    ]
},
```

From this output, you can see the ordering string is `Date Added (Descending)`. 

Use that exactly (I've removed default options)...

```php
$albums = $client->get("user/{$username}!albums", array('count' => 2, 'Order'=>'Date Added (Descending)'));
```

... and you'll get the response you expect.

If you know the exact album, you can change `$albums->Album[0]->Uris->AlbumImages` at https://github.com/lildude/phpSmug/blob/d6ddb55337f17097f2d03d9e8745f78963b96dff/examples/example-oauth.php#L80 to the exact path as per the API.

For example, if the album ID is `123456`, you'd change that line to:

```php
$images = $client->get('album/123456!images');
```

... or determine it by reviewing the results of the earlier call to get all the albums:

https://github.com/lildude/phpSmug/blob/d6ddb55337f17097f2d03d9e8745f78963b96dff/examples/example-oauth.php#L78

Removing the `, array('count' => 1)` part will return all albums.

> How do i keep my authorization alive and even if i do page refresh, it should just run the script rather than redirecting me?

You'll need to save the authentication token returned by the API to some location of your choice and then use it as detailed in the docs at https://github.com/lildude/phpSmug/blob/master/docs/authentication.md

I suspect this is your problem:

```
$option = json_encode($option);
```

You don't need to `json_encode()` the array yourself as phpSmug takes advantage of Guzzle's functionality to do that for you as part of creating the POST request. 

Try removing that line entirely.

It sounds like either your `phpSmug.php` file has somehow been duplicated within itself resulting in two declarations of `HttpRequestException` (first declared on https://github.com/lildude/phpSmug/blob/3.4/phpSmug.php#L904) or you've made changes to some other code in which you're pulling in `phpSmug.php` that is also using a `HttpRequestException` classname.

Of the two, I suspect it may be the latter, in which case the simple fix would be to change your other code or rename the class in phpSmug.

phpSmug 4 won't suffer from this problem as it now use Guzzle for the HTTP requests rather than including it's own request code.

Looking into this and the headers that come in the response from SmugMug I can see they're set to discourage caching which means something like the [guzzle-cache-middleware](https://github.com/Kevinrob/guzzle-cache-middleware) middleware I looked to use won't actually cache anything unless you force it to ignore these headers and enforce "greedy" caching.

There's also the complexity of the plethora of caching options out there. guzzle-cache-middleware has interfaces for Doctrine cache, Laravel cache, Flysystem and each of these have their own options for caching data.

Given that the SmugMug response headers don't encourage caching and the complexity involved for the various caching implementations, I'm not going to implement caching again directly into phpSmug. Instead I'll document how you can use guzzle-cache-middleware to implement caching with your choice of implementations.

Does the gallery in question have "External Embedding" set to "Off" in the gallery settings?  This is the most common cause for the behaviour you are seeing.

If it does, you'll need to use the `$f->signResource()` method for each of the URL links if you don't want to enable external links.

An example of this usage can be found in [this gist](https://gist.github.com/lildude/00f8f00cc9bdc3163c83).

In the example, the unsigned image if first and shouldn't show and the second is the signed and should show.  Keep in mind that you may see it the other way round if you're logged into SmugMug at the time of testing so make sure you test in an incognito window or ensure you're logged out.

To pull images from a specific gallery, you would need to hard-code or specify the `AlbumID` and `AlbumKey` for the specific album instead of using `{$albums['0']['id']}` and `{$albums['0']['Key']}` respectively.

To obtain the `AlbumID` and `AlbumKey`, you need to call `$f->albums_get()` which calls `[smugmug.albums.get](http://api.smugmug.com/services/api/?version=1.3.0&method=smugmug.albums.get)` which is done in all of the examples just before the `$f->images_get()` method call. For example, in [line 59 of the example-anon.php](https://github.com/lildude/phpSmug/blob/master/examples/example-anon.php#L59) example.  

All the examples pick the first album in the list returned by `$f->albums_get()` so if you know the album in the 3rd in the results, you could use:

``` php
$images = $f->images_get( "AlbumID={$albums['2']['id']}", "AlbumKey={$albums['2']['Key']}", "Heavy=1" );
```

If you're hard-coding the `AlbumID` and `AlbumKey` values, you won't need to perform the `$f->albums_get()` call when rolling out your code into production.

ProTip: phpSmug includes a [debug function](https://github.com/lildude/phpSmug/blob/master/phpSmug.php#L133) that you can use during development to review the results of any method call, for example:

``` php
$albums = $f->albums_get( 'NickName=<NICKNAME>' );
phpSmug::debug( $albums );
```

... would show the results of your `$f->albums_get()` call.

The image size shouldn't matter from phpSmug's perspective as it isn't actually doing the uploading.  Smugmug is doing the uploading itself by pulling the image directly from the URL you specify.

That said, as Smugmug is doing the pulling, why not just do a foreach() on your array without the page refresh and leave it to Smugmug to do the rest?

Ok, I've reproduced the issue.  It appears sometimes api.smugmug.com is a little slow to respond and it doesn't send any data within the 30 seconds phpSmug allows it to respond.

At the moment, there isn't an easy way to increase this time out without modifying the source, but there are two solutions I've found:
1.  Do as per my previous note and use a foreach() loop to loop through the array of URLs without the refresh and allow SmugMug to pull the images in it's own time.  You may need to increase the maximum execution time for php scripts on your server to allow this, or break up the list of image urls into smaller chunks.  This may not necessarily resolve the issue though as the API could still be slow for one of your requests.
2.  Modify phpSmug.php and add `'timeout' => 60` to the `$this->req->setConfig()` in the `__construct()` method as follows (I've added it to the end of the line):

``` php
$this->req->setConfig( array( 'adapter' => $this->adapter, 'follow_redirects' => TRUE, 'max_redirects' => 3, 'ssl_verify_peer' => FALSE, 'ssl_verify_host' => FALSE, 'connect_timeout' => 60, 'timeout' => 60 ) );
```

If this last one works for you, I'll need to create a method to make setting this easier, or possibly just increase the default to 60 seconds.

1)We have tried using foreach with out setting any timeout parameter and meta refresh, but we got an error.

2)After setting the timeout as you have mentioned in the point #2, it worked.

3)We are uploading more than 5000+ images(eac contains size aprox 8 to 10 MB) to SmugMug by creating new galleries, albums, sub albums and also doing some db update for our records, While doing all these things, the PHP script will get timed out. This is the reason why we go for meta refresh.

As of now the your point #2 is working for us, we have set "timeout=>120", please let us know is this a stable solution or is there any other better way to avoid this issue?

Good to hear you've got a working solution.  That IS a stable solution.  The default setting is 30 seconds.  You're just increasing this to 120 which should give the SmugMug API plenty of time to respond.

I'll add a helper function to a future release of phpSmug which will allow you to increase this timeout without having to modify the source.

> I need to apply the global polyfill as we load a js file seperately on older browsers to reduce unnecessary code.

Generally, I would suggest using an async `import()` for this (polyfilled into a script include if needed), but I understand not everyone has the tooling to make that work smoothly in older browsers.

@lgarron Perfect, yes works like a charm! 

> Generally, I would suggest using an async import()

In our case we serve a "legacy" and "modern" bundle in ES5 and ES7 respectively, using the "Differential Loading" pattern to only serve to clients that support either. Our polyfill file is handled in a similar way. Handling it via `import()` would be better, but muddies our code base with support conditionals, and our IE11 user base is tiny!

Many thanks for sorting this out, one less thing for me to worry about! ðŸ‘

I believe you're running up against an intentional design tradeoff: this library is actually a ponyfill rather than a polyfill. https://github.com/sindresorhus/ponyfill

I expect most users to be using modules/build systems, but if you're using the UMD definition directly in the browser, you should call `window.clipboard`. The library will itself call `navigator.clipboard` if it exists.

I'm open a PR clarifying this in the README!

I have the same problem with Firefox 78 on Windows. When I add clipboard-polyfill.promise.js to the website, then an error `Uncaught TypeError: r.read is undefined` is thrown.

I think it is caused by `var r=navigator.clipboard,o=null==r?void 0:r.read.bind(r)`

On Firefox `navigator.clipboard` exists. But `navigator.clipboard.read` does not exist. So the bind goes into an error.

Thanks for taking the time to investigate this!

Safari compat is quite annoying to repro, since Safari releases are tied to OS releases.

> I will note that the WebKit devs were pretty confused by `copyUsingTempSelection`, both by what it's trying to do and why it's considered necessary for desktop Safari.

`copyUsingTempSelection()` exists because `document.execCommand("copy")` does not trigger in WebKit (and only WebKit) if there is no selection: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=156529

Our code tries `copyUsingTempSelection()` before `copyUsingTempElem()` because adding an element to the DOM has side effects (e.g. triggering mutation observers), and I would like to avoid unnecessary side effects as much as possible.

Unfortunately, it seems that iOS and desktop diverge on the bug you're describing: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=177715

If you're still in contact with the WebKit devs, I'd appreciate comments on the two bugs I've linked in order to convey the impression that this is preventing things from working in Safari. :-)

(There are more bugs, but these are the two major ones. See https://github.com/lgarron/clipboard-polyfill/blob/master/experiment/Conclusions.md if you're interested in more details.)

> If we removed the `copyUsingTempSelection` branch so that it _does_ reach "Fallback for iOS Safari," _that does work_.

Does this not reach the "Fallback 2 for desktop Safari." branch?

Overall, I think it's worth making sure that we copy successfully at least on current (and upcoming) versions of all browsers. I'll take a closer look at this.

Do you have any good examples of what other libraries with TypeScript and or `yarn` dep management implementations do?

TypeScript source environment will still be on GitHub, just not NPM. This only changes what is pulled in when people do `yarn add clipboard-polyfill` / `npm i  clipboard-polyfill`. After a adding it through a package manager editing the source has major downsides:

1. For JavaScript devs they'd have to transpile it before being able to use it. They may not even know how to do this.
2. Edits to files in node_modules are entirely lost upon the next `yarn install`, `npm install` or when taking whatever project is being worked into a production environment. Especially for this library which targets webdevs you can be assured that everyone who takes this lib into a production environment has that environment off-site hosted somewhere; be that a VPS or something like Google Firebase.
  - And especially in the case of the latter these edits made cannot be re-applied.
3. Actual edits that other people want to do can be done through forking the github repo and doing `npm install GitHubUsername/Repo` (or, yarn add again). They could even publish their own fork to NPM, doing so doesn't void neither this package's license nor NPM's rules.

I could probably come up with a few more if I would put in the time for it but I need to focus on work too.

As for examples of other libraries, I could link my own I suppose but that's obvious bias. That said due to their download counts I will anyway:
- [Awesome Crypto (153 downloads to date)](https://yarnpkg.com/en/package/awesome-crypto)
- [Awesome Querystring (713 downloads to date)](https://yarnpkg.com/en/package/awesome-querystring)
- [Awesome Converter (154 downloads to date)](https://yarnpkg.com/en/package/awesome-converter)
- [Milky TSLint (177 downloads to date)](https://yarnpkg.com/en/package/milky-tslint)
- [nintendo-switch-eshop (7089 downloads since rework in TS on January 19th last)](https://yarnpkg.com/en/package/nintendo-switch-eshop) (note: this is primarily Immfranco's lib but I am now also a maintainer to the github repo due to my work of porting it over)

And beside these there are even big JS based libs that do not publish their source but rather just their distribution builds, for example [Jimp](https://yarnpkg.com/en/package/jimp). Or heck even the enormously popular library [React](https://yarnpkg.com/en/package/react) doesn't publish their source.

Also to cover some of my own points with some of the knowledge I have gained since I made it:

> Get rid of Webpack, it is a module for commonJS so just transpiling with TSC is enough. To cover uglification I added uglifyjs-folder

There is actually a golden rule emerging these days that says `Rollup for libraries, Webpack for apps`. This golden rule was spearheaded [when React switched their build process to Rollup](https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/9327) and you can read the "why" in that PR. Rollup can directly process TypeScript, I've created a single library myself with Rollup so far. Oh and [here is a medium article on the topic](https://medium.com/webpack/webpack-and-rollup-the-same-but-different-a41ad427058c) (can't share this lib as it's private-to-work)

> Get rid of Makefile

I can see where you're coming from here. The problem is that on a barebones system (especially Windows) `make` is not available as a command while, since we're doing NodeJS, `npm` is which is why I promoted the switch to npm scripts. On the topic of "middle grounds" and "status quo", what we could do is first move all the actions that makefile currently does to NPM scripts and then in the Makefile we call those scripts. That way you can continue to use Makefile the way you always have and other users can just use the NPM scripts.

> Jest framework stuff etc

Jest is primarily for unit testing. For E2E testing there are libs such as [Google Chrome's Puppeteer](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/puppeteer) or [TestCafe](https://github.com/DevExpress/testcafe). Admittedly I haven't explored either yet although I do have an open story on my work's tracker board to do so, so I expect that I can say more about this in a couple of months .... hopefully. Regardless, for unit testing Jest already makes it all a LOT easier since it requires basically no setup at all as opposed to some of the alternatives. This being because it's a framework as opposed to a library (like Mocha, which requires Chai for assertions and Sinon for stubbing for example).

> Folder structure

Well I suppose it's not all that necessary

> Package.json cleanups

I'll... need to check the stuff like I said. Or get the repo back. I sent the ticket to GitHub support btw. Same counts for the TS compiler issues I found. Oh and Rollup does run the full TS compiler btw... I noticed that a while ago myself.

As the error message says, Firefox requires the clipboard API to be called inside a short-running event handler. `await axios.get('/api/path')` can be a relatively long round-trip. Chrome has a bit of a leniency period, but it will also fail on slow connections to your server.

The best option is either to prepare the data ahead of time, or show a messages to the user that you are preparing the data and asking them to trigger another action to actually copy the data.

See https://github.com/w3c/clipboard-apis/issues/41 for proposals to handle delayed clipboard data in the future.

Note: I was originally planning to do this in a `v3.0.0` release, but this is now published as `v2.7.0` because it should be backwards-compatible in most environments.

The `default` export will be removed in `v3.0.0`.

If anything `import * as` versus `import default from` would be covered by TypeScript with ESModuleInterop afaik - and to be frank not using ESModuleInterop does developers more harm in issues to address than good. Way too many JS based libs that just don't export ES6 / TS friendly and basically require the compiler flag. 

Aside from that, when following the semantic versioning spec it should be perfectly okay to include breaking changes in major version changes so you as a lib developer shouldn't be fussed about creating such as long as you change the major version. It is up to implementors (like me in the future perhaps ðŸ¤”) to be wary of major version upgrades - and preferebly install with the ^version spec.

I agree with @Favna, `esModuleInterop` should work fine and is also necessary for many other packages, e.g. `react` (and `create-react-app` sets it by default).

From what I understand Babel also handles it automatically and the convention for most packages indeed seems to be `import default` (or `import { explicit }`) rather than `import * as`, so I hope you can reconsider this change.
As of v3.0.0, there's no default export any more!

> import { clipboard } from clipboard-polyfill

There is nothing named `clipboard` in the exports, so I don't think this could ever work. Is there something I'm missing?

> newer projects that have to use an import statement like `import * as clipboard from 'clipboard-polyfill'`

Every time I look into this, I get really frustrated with the state of Javascript module compatibility. My understanding is that based on how you're doing this, either of `import clipboard from 'clipboard-polyfill'` or `import * as clipboard from 'clipboard-polyfill'` might work or fail, but the former is "the right way" to import a default export.

If there's a way I can export a single value that:

- works with the same import statement everywhere, and
- does not break backwards compatibility,

I'd love to use that.

(Note that I don't consider it a good solution to add a `clipboard` member on `ClipboardPolyfill` referencing itself. ðŸ˜•)

I agree that module compatibility can sometimes be frustrating. My project only supports ES6 imports and it depends on copy to clipboard being available in all browsers. The previous version of the project works fine with clipboard-polyfill but the new version in development requires that it can be imported with either 
`import { IMPORTNAME } from 'clipboard-polyfill'`

Just in case you're not aware since it generally would require looking at the MAN doc, the easiest way for this is:

```sh
npm version <patch|minor|major> #depending on the version increase
git commit -s --amend --no-edit
``` 

Explanation:

`npm version <patch|minor|major>` bumps the package.json version by whatever you specify while adhering semantic versioning. For example `major` from `2.72.89` would go `3.0.0` or minor from same `2.73.0`. It then creates a git commit of `v<whatever_new_version>` and a matching tag (both that `v` and the tag creation can be configured) 

`git commit -s --amend --no-edit` amends the commit that was just created. `-s` specifies that you want to add a `Signed off by AUTHOR <EMAIL>` wherein AUTHOR and EMAIL are the ones you configured in `~/.gitconfig` (`%USERPROFILE%/.gitconfig` on windows) (or through `git config --global user.email` etc) and finally `--no-edit` specifies that it shouldn't open the as-configured default git text editor to edit the commit message.

Naturally you can also automate all of this with a bash Function:

```sh
#!/bin/bash

function librelease() {
  if [[ $1 == major ]] || [[ $1 == minor ]] || [[ $1 == patch ]]
    then
      npm version "$1"
      git commit -s --amend --no-edit
    else
      echo "Please provide either major, minor or patch as first argument to this function"
  fi
}
```

I was referring specifically to signing commits using something like GPG (or S/MIME). The ecosystem doesn't really use this for verification, and I would prefer not to complicate building/publishing any more than needed, so I'm not going to do this any time soon.

Would love to see this get merged. I'd prefer not to ship any extra polyfills.

The main point of this library is that it Just Worksâ„¢ï¸ across as many browsers as possible, so I want IE to work out of the box.

However, I'd be open to a PR with suitably designed way to opt out of shipping a separate polyfill fallback (note that the polyfill is not *used* in modern browsers as of #59, so the main remaining concern should be code bloat), e.g.
- a build that outputs two JS files (in a way such that it's easy to use the correct one), or
- avoids loading the polyfill if the module system can already guarantee one.

Examples of similar projects successfully supporting an optional polyfill like this would be useful to know.

One example of a project that successfully asks people to use their own polyfill is React. From [JavaScript Environment Requirements][js-env] for React:

> React 16 depends on the collection types Map and Set. If you support older browsers and devices which may not yet provide these natively (e.g. IE < 11), consider including a global polyfill in your bundled application, such as core-js or babel-polyfill.

Seems fairly reasonable to have a BYOP (bring your own polyfill) stance if you need to support older browsers or are including your own polyfill already (ie. core-js) and don't need a duplicate.

  [js-env]: https://reactjs.org/docs/javascript-environment-requirements.html

> I'm wondering if there is another way to make copy works in my scenario that keep AJAX async (as it should be).

At the moment, there is not. Browsers require specifying the data to be copied synchronously at copy time (and the copy action must be triggered in direct response to a user gesture). If you absolutely cannot have your data ready synchronously, I suggest having a button to generate the data, which then reveals an actual copy button when the data is ready.

See https://github.com/w3c/clipboard-apis/issues/41 for possible better approaches in the future.

From a first glance, it looks like you're trying to load @zenorocha's clipboard library, and then calling this library once it has loaded. You should pick one or the other. ;-)

If you're trying to use this library, can you modify [this writeText example](https://github.com/lgarron/clipboard-polyfill/blob/0b84df8d0eff7a8b642143e03166c95a9f1b212a/index.html#L32) to suit your needs?

Make sure to call `clipboard.writeText()` directly in an event handler for a user gesture (e.g. a click). If you wait for an AJAX call to respond, then the browser won't consider your copy action to be triggered by the last user gesture, and block it. (Chrome has a 1-second grace period for this. If your code runs twice and the second request returns from the cache in less than a second, this may explain the behaviour where it succeeds only the second time).
Have you been able to get this to work? :-)

> But if the file is loaded on demand, it doesn't work first click.

This is expected. Loading the script on demand incurs a delay, and you need copy to the clipboard without delay from your event handler.

If you want to be able to copy on the first click, you'll have to load the script ahead of time.

Cool, thanks for opening this. A few thoughts:

* Can the callback receive information about what was actually copied, for it to inspect? I guess a `ClipboardPolyfill.DT`.
* If a copy was not user-initiated, I wouldn't want the callback to happen at all. The point of `interceptCopy` is to intercept user-initiated copies--why would I need to intercept a copy I initiated myself? Maybe it should even be called `interceptUserCopy`. (If a copy was not initiated by the user, then presumably it was initiated by `clipboard-polyfill`, right? It should be possible to know when an event is due to the library itself.)
* I don't quite understand what the semantics of an asynchronous callback would be. What if the user did a paste before the async action was completed? They would get the original, un-intercepted copy data, right? I think synchronous is fine--I wouldn't expect to be able to do time-consuming things in event handlers anway. (If you need to do an additional async call to `execCommand` under the hood because of browser bugginess that's fine, as long as there's a very short window in which the user could potentially sneak in a paste and get the wrong result.)

Actually, maybe there are some use-cases where you'd want to intercept copies you initiated yourself. And maybe copies can be initiated outside of this library. But in any case, I don't think the "user-initiated" flag is super necessary--if the client of this library is in the business of triggering their own copies, and they want to ignore them in the intercept function, it's not too unreasonable to make them handle that themselves.

In summary, I think it should either "intercept all copies" and provide no flag, or "intercept user-initiated copies only" if possible.

What is the use case?

Conceptually:
- This unnecessarily muddles levels of abstraction.
- One presumably wouldn't write a Javascript function to the clipboard. Passing it in the same way as a regular value would be confusing (personally, I would expect that to convert the function to a string or some serialized format, not to run the function).
- The API currently provides an imperative functions, not listeners. It is not normal to accept functions as arguments unless they are callbacks. Since both callbacks and Promise-based APIs are still in common use, I would prefer not to add a new _kind_ of function that you can give to the API.

So it seems clear to me that running a function on behalf of the caller is "not the job" of a library like this.

However, I'm not against adding it here if it provides strong practical convenience.
Are there cases where `clipboard.copy(fn)` is useful in addition to `clipboard.copy(fn())`, and where the developer cannot be reasonably be expected to handle it themselves?
Are there other precedents?

> I initially assumed I could pass a function and was surprised it wasn't in there!

Hmm, I can reproduce the issue, but I'm not sure whether there is anything to fix â€“ this is the direct behaviour of using:

```
e.clipboardData.setData("text/html", "http://example.com/index.php?oid=1&pid=2");
```

In HTML, `&` encodes `&`, so this copies the markup as it was specified.
I don't think it's appropriate to try to add extra layers of escaping for your use case â€“ it could lead to unexpected behaviour for other use cases (ones that do rely on unescaping markup characters), and trying to cover cases across all browsers could lead to an unending game of whackamole.

As a workaround, you could either copy plain text, or find a workaround in LibreOffice ([this](https://help.libreoffice.org/Writer/Turning_Off_AutoCorrect) or [this](https://help.libreoffice.org/Common/Replace#Replacement_table))? It seems like undesirable behaviour that LibreOffice does that replacement on pasted text.

Unfortunately there is no workaround in LibreOffice. I already filed a bug ticket over there, but I doubt that it will be fixed because rich text link copying works from all programs that I have tested so far. Only  clipboard.js fails because it cannot generate a valid http query url. By the way W3C requires that an ampersand character must be http-encoded if it is ambigous. All major browsers follow this recommendation by http-encoding the ampersand in query strings when copying a link in rich-text-mode with the effect that LibreOffice is able to correctly interpret the url.

The way it is, clipboard.js cannot be used to reliably generate URL Links that can be used in LibreOffice and possibly other programs as well. Simply passing strings in a 1:1 manner and not trying to decode anything would solve all these issues at once.

What happens if you use zenorocha/clipboard.js or the API itself?

It seems to me that you're passing a string meant as "unencoded HTML" to an API that takes encoded HTML. If you write an HTML document and would like `http://example.com/index.php?oid=1&pid=2` to show up as text on the page, you will have to [write it in the source as `http://example.com/index.php?oid=1&amp;pid=2`](https://jsfiddle.net/d1y9115g/1/).

> Simply passing strings in a 1:1 manner and not trying to decode anything would solve all these issues at once.

`clipboard.js` itself does not attempt to decode anything. If you specify that a string containing `&` should be interpreted as `text/html`, then I only see one correct behaviour.
In order to support what I think you're asking for, we'd have to _add_ (un)decoding where there is currently none.

If you need to copy rich text containing strings with escape characters, would it be sufficient for you to create the rich text in via DOM APIs?
Consider this:

```
var span = document.createElement("span");
span.textContent = "http://example.com/index.php?oid=1&pid=2";
clipboard.copy(span)
```
It seems `document.queryCommandSupported("copy")` will get us most of the way there.

Idea: add the following flags to `folderify`
- `--cache` (caches the mask in the cache dir)
- `--cache-dir` (default: `~/.folderify/cache`)
- `--restore` (re-runs folderify from the cache dir on all folders that still exist)

Sorry I'm a few years late. After seeing the current install instructions, I thought it might be simpler if there was a brew tap available (which I've created [here](https://github.com/harens/homebrew-folderify)).

folderify can then be updated  more easily, and imagemagick is automatically installed.

```shell
brew tap harens/folderify
brew install folderify
```
I would gladly transfer ownership to yourself if you're happy with it.
That's neat! Do you know if this is the kind of thing that Homebrew itself would accept?

There's various criteria that the formula and folderify itself will have to meet (such as the [following](https://docs.brew.sh/Acceptable-Formulae)) but there's certainly no harm in trying and I'll give it my best shot! 

I'll send a PR over to them once I think the formula is ready, and I'd be really grateful if you could take a look at the issue I raised here https://github.com/lgarron/folderify/issues/42 to help speed things up. Thanks

I sent a PR over to them: https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/pull/58907, and it was approved! ðŸŽ‰

The final result can be seen [here](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/blob/4fbdc888bcd332fe1317e08b9cb99044348a3505/Formula/folderify.rb). Now, all you need to run is the following:

```
brew install folderify
```
I'm going to archive the [original tap](https://github.com/harens/homebrew-folderify), although you're still welcome to have it if you want. Thanks for your help (and the great software)!

With the convenience of target assignment and `--reveal`, I don't think this is necessary.

It also doesn't appear to simple trivial to implement.

- It appears that above 32px, the `@2x` version of a particular resolution is the same as the (regular) next resolution.
- `.icns` embeds `.png`: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Icon_Image_format#Icon_types

Using `pngcrush` on the input files didn't seem to reduce the output filesize, but removing redundant files did.

While the 128x128@2x image is the same as the 256x256 image, leaving out the former results in pixelated upscaling.

![screenshot 2014-11-27 18 45 33](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/248078/5223125/9d85cff0-7665-11e4-88d2-a8cdab3ecf28.png)
![screenshot 2014-11-27 18 45 27](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/248078/5223126/9d89c560-7665-11e4-99c2-877d408caa85.png)

It's an unnecessary syntactical bit, yes, but the main thing to realizes is that a trailing slash isn't the focus of the element. When I think of an ``, I know it doesn't need closing, so I know I don't need to go looking for an indicator of it _being_ closed. I just think ``. Same with `
`, `
`, etc.

This falls in the same camp as the 'no final semi-colon'.
While I personally always add the closing slash to all these type of tags, and the final semi-colon for that matter, it is not necessary, it just makes me happy.
This is a code 'guide' to help give us all a base of good coding practices, and direction, not a coding law/requirement.
Take what you need from the guide, and try to understand it's principles, and hopefully it will help you become a better programmer.
I think the main idea of the guide is to bring us all together, so when I open your code I'm not lost, making us more productive.

I don't mean to sound dick-ish or arrogant, it's simply matter of fact. If you use tabs, someone's dev environment might have 8-space tabs and you 4-space. With _soft tabs_, the same spaces in one piece of code can be copy-pasted to another person's computer and will render the exact same because a space is a space. One person's tab doesn't always equal another person's tab.

Out of curiosity is there any particular reason that you use 2 spaces instead of 4? For me personally I find it harder to see indentations when they are only 2 spaces long but it could just be what I am used to.
You can fit more onto the screen, and you also save space by having two spaces instead of four.

I disagree.

It is more readable to use hard indents, and then mnify your code for
production.

Human readability is more important during development, and simple
minification like Grunt solves any specific issues for production.

Zlatan VasoviÄ‡ - _ZDroid_

The `keywords` meta tag does not help your web ranking at all.

"About a decade ago, search engines judged pages only on the content of web pages, not any so-called "off-page" factors such as the links pointing to a web page. In those days, keyword meta tags quickly became an area where someone could stuff often-irrelevant keywords without typical visitors ever seeing those keywords. Because the keywords meta tag was so often abused, many years ago Google began disregarding the keywords meta tag."

http://googlewebmastercentral.blogspot.in/2009/09/google-does-not-use-keywords-meta-tag.html

Why couldn't you simply solve this in your PHP using single quotes?

```
echo '<a href="$href">';
```

PHP doesn't allow variables inside single quotes and treats them as literals.

```
 $href = "foo";
 echo '<a href="$href">'; // outputs <a href="$href">
 echo "<a href='$href'>"; // outputs <a href='foo'>
```

This is a very common idiom in PHP.
This is an HTML and CSS code guide, so it doesn't take any other programming language into account for the most part. That sounds like a pretty shitty limitation on PHP's part though :laughing:.

I'll take the opportunity of this issue and ask why there shouldn't be spaces after commas in `rgb()` and `rgba()`. Any particular reason to this contradiction to the "Comma-separated values should include a space after each comma"-rule, except for personal preference?

It is better for readability.

`rgb(0,0,0,0)` allows you to read the numbers as fast as possible.

`rgb(0, 0, 0, 0)` doesn't allow you to focus on the numbers.

I think that `rgb(215,106,180,.9)` is better.

Edit: that is my opinion, but not everybody writes code on the same way.

Thanks.

2014-03-05 17:51 GMT+01:00 Mark Otto notifications@github.com:

> The guide was updated yesterday to better explain the balance between this
> and the guideline quoted by @hnrch02 https://github.com/hnrch02.
> 
> Comma-separated values should include a space after each comma.
> 
> Don't include spaces after commas within rgb() or rgba() colors to
> differentiate color values from CSS properties that allow multiple values
> that are already separated by a comma and space. Also, don't prefix values
> with a leading zero (e.g., .5 instead of 0.5).
> 
> These two guidelines go hand-in-hand. The goal is to make rgb(), rgba(),
> hsl(), and hsla() values appear as a single meta value within your CSS.
> Multiple values, like those of a box-shadow, should have a space after the
> comma. Color values, however, shouldn't, as a means of differentiating the
> two.
> 
> Here's a longer example of both these rules combined:
> 
> /\* With the space after commas within color values. _/.element {
>   color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.75);
>   background-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5);
>   box-shadow: 0 1px 2px rgba(0, 3px, 6px, 0.15), inset 0 1px 0 rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5);}
> /_ Without the space, but with the space between multiple values. */.element {
>   color: rgba(255,255,255,.75);
>   background-color: rgba(0,0,0,.5);
>   box-shadow: 0 1px 2px rgba(0,3px,6px,.15), inset 0 1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,.5);}
> 
> That's a rather extreme example, and honestly one that doesn't make that
> much sense color-wise [image: :laughing:]. However, it demonstrates the
> difference in how the scannability of CSS is affected by too much spacing
> within property values.
> 
> And yes, that section should probably be updated to include these other
> color options and the rect value.
>

I always use this ordering:

as discussed on twitter, yes...this seems to be the least bad way to work around it (balancing the need for iframes to provide a title, as otherwise accessibility checkers - usually rightly - complain, and the need for not being overly repetitive and verbose when navigating with a screen reader)

(and, again, just to reiterate that the `<title>` in the actual document loaded inside the `<iframe>` is generally not announced - at least not in from memory/from testing in a few browser/AT combos on regular settings, regardless ... the main issue here is more that the `title="..."` and then the `aria-label` on the actual links was a bit too much ... `<title>` itself is irrelevant)

Thanks for chiming in!

Can you check please NDA or whatever program you use how is the situation for a given embedded button from the main page on the live docs and on this [PR preview](https://optimistic-swanson-3a1e25.netlify.app/)?

So that I have a clear view of the issue. Thanks!

the various browser/AT combos all behave subtly differently when encountering frames, and it also depends how you navigate (e.g. TABbing from control to control versus using reading keys etc). But yes, from quick testing, this is the least bad approach (fundamentally, because of the use of `<iframe>`, this will always be more verbose than strictly necessary, but assuming that pages will use these sparingly, it's not as bad).

as an example of convoluted/verbose behavior, on MacOS/Chrome when encountering an iframe, VoiceOver will have two separate stops when you navigate with reading keys (CTRL+ALT+cursor left/right): one for the "group", and then one for the "frame" (and then the user has to actively say they want to navigate into the iframe, and then they'll get to the link inside). For the frame, it seems Chrome does expose/use the `<title>` of the iframe itself (no other browser/AT combo I checked does this though, so uncommon).

The old/current iframe is thus experienced like this

Star twbs/bootstrap on GitHub, group
Star twbs/bootstrap on GitHub, frame

With this PR, it at least limits this a bit to

GitHub, group
Star twbs/bootstrap on GitHub, frame

MacOS/Safari is less verbose with VoiceOver, and only announces the frame itself (using the `title="..."`).

The old/current one is announced as

Star twbs/bootstrap on GitHub, frame

With this PR, it's

GitHub, frame

Windows/Chrome and NVDA only announces the frame (no extra "group"), so here the announcement is similar to MacOS/Safari. If navigating by TAB, it currently announces quite verbosely, when jumping to a link inside the iframe from outside the iframe:

Star twbs/bootstrap on GitHub  frame, Star twbs/bootstrap on GitHub  visited  link

With this PR, it limits it to something more manageable

GitHub  frame, Star twbs/bootstrap on GitHub  visited  link

Anyway, long story short, this change reduces unnecessary verbosity a bit. For the rest, you just gotta live with it as it's due to the nature of the solution that was chosen.

I used `ghbtns.com/github-btn.html?*` as the URL and it seems now it's cached regardless of the queries.

I still think you'd get even better results doing a redirect.
Now:
```
https://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html?param=1
https://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html?param=2
```
are two different cache objects (cache hit ratio <100%, likely 50-70%), but the redirect done with Page Rule is generated on the edge (no latency and no hitting the origin), then
```
https://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html#param=1
https://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html#param=2
```
are just one file `https://ghbtns.com/github-btn.html` from the browser's point of view.

Then this PR reads data you need from URL fragment, which is still accessible from JavaScript. Because you are hosing the code, you can make the change that will automatically apply to all existing users.

End result: 100% cache hit ratio.

Obviously, in the end it's up to you.

First of all, I really appreciate you taking the time to make a PR ðŸ™‚ It's just that I'm trying to make one change at a time. Also, I'm not a fan of adding a redirect, unless we really need to. With my current solution, which doesn't involve any code changes or a redirect, our cache ratio went from 0.4% to ~88%. Now, it might not be close to 100%, but I think it's a pretty good improvement! Our free plan allows for 3 Page Rules, but I think it is enough right now. Here is what I have currently deployed: I plan to experiment with adding an Edge Cache TTL of 2 hours; I'm not sure of the effect this will have.

You already have it cached for 2 hours, unless the origin sends `Cache-Control` header specifying otherwise.
https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/en-us/articles/200172516-Understanding-Cloudflare-s-CDN#h_51422705-42d0-450d-8eb1-5321dcadb5bc

You may actually benefit from raising the Edge Cache TTL either with `Cache-Control` (I don't think GitHub Pages allow to control this) or setting `Edge Cache TTL` Page Rule (note: only one rule will match the URL, but you can set several settings inside the same rule).

The only thing I'm not 100% sure about is the 403 error code case, which one might hit if they hit the GitHub API rate limit.

>You already have it cached for 2 hours, unless the origin sends Cache-Control header specifying otherwise.

The origin (GitHub Pages) sends `max-age=600`.

I'm still seeing this behavior under some network environments, though it starts to work after I switched to a proxy. Any ideas why it happens?

The issue is likely due to Github API Ratelimiting. When using the API in unauthenticated mode you are stuck with 60 requests per hour, which is obviously vary limiting.

To get around this I actually build a small [Github API service](https://stars.gitconsensus.com/) that logs in (raising the API limit to 5000 per hour) and implements caching to stretch that rate limit out pretty far (if the ratelimit gets hit the cache returns no matter what- theres no eviction, just occasionally stale data). From there I [forked another button project](https://gitbuttons.tedivm.com/) and configured it to use that API.

Y U NO HTTPS?
But seriously, I would love to see HTTPS support. :+1:
:+1: Wish I could use this!

I think if/when the JS thing happens here, that will solve the https problem. For the time being though, it's not something I've any experience with and won't get into just yet. Open to more feedback and thoughts though.

If it's a JS thing that you paste onto your own page and is loaded entirely from your own page, CSS and all, that would solve the problem. 

But if you're on an HTTPS page and it tries to load something from an HTTP site, most browsers will fail to load the HTTP content, and give you an error along the lines of "Failed to load unsafe content." A simple way to test this is with [EFF's HTTPS-everywhere](https://www.eff.org/https-everywhere), which forces HTTPS connections on *.github.com. GitHub Pages that use the iframe version won't load the buttons, since there is no https://ghbtns.com/.

ghtbtns.com is now the only reason why I'm getting mixed content warnings on my GH pages. Iframes aren't as bad as plain scripts since they'll still be "executed" by default, but it would be great to get TLS support.

Cross Origin requests headers are absolutely important, when you're building an API. However, I don't think that it's useful to set it to `*` for all requests by default. You may easily introduce unnecessary security issues by doing that. It's more useful to have those headers added for each endpoint independently, when needed. Additionally, it's important to allow users to have more control over what headers are exposed and what verbs are allowed.
